Akusala is defined as blameable and undesirable-resultant. Abeyant is defined as the opposite of both. It is not capable of resulting.

original: Tattha kusalacittaṃ ekavīsatividhaṃ hoti, tadidaṃ bhūmito catubbidhaṃ hoti – kāmāvacaraṃ, rūpāvacaraṃ, arūpāvacaraṃ, lokuttarañceti.

translated: is glad, gladdened, and on that acount, without being urged by others, does meritorious deeds consisting in giving, etc.,🔽then his profitable consciousness is firstly of the kind called “accompanied by joy” and “associated with knowledge” and “unprompted” .

analyzed: etāni pana cittāni bhavanti iti pakāsaye

translated: But it is of many kinds according to the difference of object, occurring as it does in the earth kasiṇa, etc., as appropriate.

analyzed: sabbam pana etam rūpāvacara bhāvanā puñña vasa ppavattam yathānurūpam rūpāvacara upapatti nipphādakam
translated: And all this, which is the accumulation of merit consisting in development of the fine-material sphere, produces rebirth-linking as fine-material resultant according to its kind.

analyzed: evam tāva rūpāvacara kusalam veditabbam
translated: This, in the first place, is how the profitable of the fine-material sphere should be understood.

original: Sesesu pana dvīsu arūpāvacarakusalacittaṃ tāva upekkhāvedanāyogabhedato ekavidhaṃ,
analyzed: sesesu pana dvīsu arūpāvacara kusala cittam tāva upekkhā vedanā yoga bhedato ekavidham
translated: As regards the remaining two, firstly, the immaterial-sphere profitable is of one kind according to the division of equanimity as feeling.

analyzed: savatthuka avatthuka bhedataḥ duvidham hīna majjhima paṇīta bhedato tividham ārammaṇa bhedato
translated: trifold as inferior, medium, and superior,🔽fourfold as to its object,

original: catubbidhaṃ. Kasiṇugghāṭimākāsaṃ, tattha pavattaviññāṇaṃ, tassa apagamo, ākiñcaññāyatananti
analyzed: catubbidham kasiṇugghāṭim ākāsam tattha pavatta viññāṇam tassa apagamaḥ ākiñcaññāyatanan ti
translated: which is the space of the kasiṇa, the consciousness occurring there, its disappearance, and the base consisting of nothingness.

original: idamassa catubbidhamārammaṇaṃ. Yathāpaṭipāṭiyā etassārammaṇassa bhedato catubbidhaṃ🔽hoti. Seyyathidaṃ – sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ
analyzed: idam assa catubbidham ārammaṇam yathā paṭipāṭiyā etassa ārammaṇassa bhedato catubbidham  hoti sā iyyathidam sabbaso rūpa saññānam samatikkamā paṭigha saññānam atthaṅgamā nānatta saññānam
translated: This is its fourfold object. It is fourfold according to the analysis of its object in the way already stated.🔽That is to say: “With the complete surmounting of perceptions of matter, with the disappearance of perceptions of resistance, with non-attention to perceptions of variety, aware of ‘unbounded space,’ he enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of boundless space” ,

analyzed: amanasikārāḥ ākāsānañcāyatana saññā sahagatam viññāṇañcāyatana saññā sahagatam ākiñcaññāyatana saññā sahagatam
translated: and so on up to “With the complete surmounting of the base consisting of boundless consciousness, aware of ‘there is nothing,’ he enters upon and dwells in the base consisting of nothingness” .

analyzed: nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana saññā sahagatan ti idam catubbidham arūpāvacara kusala cittam nāma
translated: This is the fourfold profitable consciousness belonging to the immaterial sphere.

analyzed: sabbam pana etam arūpāvacara bhāvanā puñña vasa ppavattam yathānurūpam arūpa upapatti nipphādakam
translated: And all this, which is the outcome of the merit of development of the immaterial sphere, produces rebirth-linking in the immaterial sphere according to its kind.

analyzed: hoti evam arūpa avacara kusala cittam veditabbam
translated: This is how the profitable consciousness belonging to the immaterial sphere should be understood.

original: Itaraṃ pana lokuttarakusalacittaṃ nibbānārammaṇato ekavidhaṃ, niyatāniyatavatthukabhedato
analyzed: itaram pana lokuttara kusala cittam nibbāna ārammaṇato ekavidham niyata aniyata vatthuka bhedato
translated: But the other kind of profitable consciousness of the supramundane class is of one kind as having Nibbāna as its object.🔽It is of two kinds as classed as with fixed and with unfixed object.

original: duvidhaṃ, tīhi vimokkhamukhehi pattabbato tividhaṃ, catumaggayogabhedato catubbidhaṃ.
analyzed: duvidham tīhi vimokkha mukhehi pattabbato tividham catu magga yoga bhedataḥ catubbidham
translated: It is of three kinds as attainable by means of the three doors to deliverance.🔽It is of four kinds as classed according to the four paths.

analyzed: sā iyyathidam sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsa saññojana ppahāna karam sotāpatti magga cittam
translated: That is to say, the consciousness of the path of stream-entry is that which effects the abandonment of the fetters of personality view, uncertainty, and misapprehension of virtue and duty;🔽the consciousness of the path of once-return is that which effects the reduction of greed, hatred and delusion;

analyzed: rāga dosa mohānam tanutta karam sakadāgāmi magga cittam kāma rāga byāpādānam niravasesa pahāna karam
translated: the consciousness of the path of non-return is that which effects the complete abandonment of sense-desire, resentment, and wrong view;

original: anāgāmimaggacittaṃ, rūparāgaarūparāgamānauddhaccaavijjāpahānakaraṃ arahattamaggacittanti🔽idaṃ catubbidhaṃ lokuttarakusalacittaṃ nāma. Ekekaṃ panettha jhānaṅgayogabhedato
analyzed: anāgāmi magga cittam rūpa rāga arūpa rāga māna auddhacca avijjā apahāna karam arahatta magga cittam ti  idam catubbidham lokuttara kusala cittam nāma ekekam pana itthā jhā aṅga yoga bhedataḥ
translated: the consciousness of the path of Arahantship is that which effects the abandonment of greed for form, greed for the formless, conceit , agitation, and ignorance.🔽This is called the fourfold supramundane profitable consciousness. And each of these is of five kinds according to the division of the jhāna factors,

original: pañcavidhaṃ hoti, tasmā vīsatividhaṃ hoti. Sabbaṃ panetaṃ lokuttarabhāvanāpuññavasappavattaṃ
analyzed: pañcavidham hoti tasmai vīsatividham hoti sabbam pana etam lokuttara bhāvanā puñña vasa ppavattam
translated: so the total is twenty kinds. And all this is the occurrence of the merit consisting in the development of the supramundane.

original: maggānurūpaphalappavattiyā cattāro ariyapuggale abhinipphādeti. Evaṃ lokuttarakusalaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: magga anurūpa phala ppavattiyā cattāro ariya puggale abhinipphādeti evam lokuttara kusalam veditabbam
translated: and he produces the four noble persons by the occurrence of the fruit in conformity with the path. This is how the supramundane profitable should be understood.

original: Kāme aṭṭheva rūpe ca, pañca cattārirūpisu;
analyzed: kāme aṭṭha iva rūpe ca pañca cattārirūpisu
translated: In the sense-desire, fine-material, and immaterial,

analyzed: cattāraḥ uttarān evam kusalān ekavīsati  kusala akusala apagatena satā
translated: And in the supramundane too, the profitable is of twenty-one kinds.🔽The profitable that is profitable by being dissociated from the unprofitable,

original: Kusale kusalena ca yaṃ kusalaṃ;🔽Catubhūmigataṃ muninā vasinā,
analyzed: kusale kusalena ca yam kusalam  catu bhūmi gatam muninā vasinā
translated: And that which is profitable by being associated with the profitable,🔽All that has been tasted by me, tasted,

analyzed: lapitam lapitam mayā
translated: By the Sage who has gone to the end of the four planes.

original: Akusalaṃ pana bhūmito ekavidhaṃ kāmāvacarameva, niyatāniyatavatthuvasena ca ekahetukaduhetukavasena🔽ca paṭisandhijanakājanakavasena ca duvidhaṃ, tīhi vedanāhi yogato ca lobhamūlaṃ dosamūlaṃ
analyzed: akusalam pana bhūmitaḥ ekavidham kāmāvacaram eva niyata aniyata vatthu vasena ca eka hetuka duhetuka vasena  ca paṭisandhi janaka ajanaka vasena ca duvidham tīhi vedanāhi yogato ca lobha mūlam dosa mūlam
translated: The unprofitable is of one kind as to plane, being confined to the sense-desire plane only. It is of two kinds as to whether the object is definite or indefinite, and as to whether it has one root-cause or two root-causes,

original: mohamūlanti mūlato ca tividhaṃ hoti. Tattha lobhamūlaṃ pana somanassupekkhādiṭṭhippayogabhedato
analyzed: moha mūlanti mūlato ca tividham hoti tattha lobha mūlam pana somanassa upekkhā diṭṭhi ppayoga bhedato
translated: and as to whether or not it generates rebirth-linking. It is of three kinds as to whether it is associated with the three kinds of feeling, and as to whether it has greed, or hate, or delusion as its root. Herein, that with greed as its root is of eight kinds as joy, equanimity, and false view, and as to whether it is accompanied by, or unaccompanied by, knowledge.

original: aṭṭhavidhaṃ hoti. Seyyathidaṃ – somanassasahagataṃ diṭṭhigatasampayuttaṃ asaṅkhārikamekaṃ,
analyzed: aṭṭhavidham hoti seyyathidam somanassa sahagatam diṭṭhi gata sampayuttam asaṅkhārikam ekam
translated: It is of one kind as accompanied by joy and associated with false view and unprompted.

original: sasaṅkhārikamekaṃ, somanassasahagataṃ diṭṭhigatavippayuttaṃ asaṅkhārikamekaṃ, sasaṅkhārikamekaṃ,🔽upekkhāsahagataṃ diṭṭhigatasampayuttaṃ asaṅkhārikamekaṃ, sasaṅkhārikamekaṃ, upekkhāsahagataṃ
analyzed: sa saṅkhārikam ekam somanassa sahagatam diṭṭhi gata vippayuttam asaṅkhārikam ekam sa saṅkhārikam ekam  upekkhā sahagatam diṭṭhi gata sampayuttam asaṅkhārikam ekam sa saṅkhārikam ekam upekkhā sahagatam
translated: One with applied thought and sustained thought, associated with joy, dissociated from knowledge, unprompted, and one prompted.🔽One with applied thought and sustained thought, associated with equanimity, associated with wrong view, unprompted, and one prompted.

original: diṭṭhigatavippayuttaṃ asaṅkhārikamekaṃ, sasaṅkhārikamekanti.🔽Yadā hi “natthi kāmesu ādīnavo”tiādinā nayena micchādiṭṭhiṃ purakkhatvā kevalaṃ haṭṭhatuṭṭho
analyzed: diṭṭhi gata vippayuttam asaṅkhārikam ekam sa saṅkhārikam ekam ti  yadā hi na atthi kāmesu ādīnavaḥ ti ādinā nayena micchādiṭṭhim purakkhatvā kevalam haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ
translated: One with applied thought and sustained thought, associated with equanimity, dissociated from wrong view, unprompted, and one prompted.

original: kāme vā paribhuñjati, diṭṭhamaṅgalādīni vā sārato pacceti sabhāvatikkheneva anussāhitena
analyzed: kāme vā paribhuñjati diṭṭha maṅgala ādīni vā sārataḥ pacceti sabhāvatikkhena iva anussāhitena
translated: When, by the method stated thus, “There is no danger in sensual desires,” etc., he enjoys sensual desires or believes in lucky signs, etc., only with a mind that is pleased and satisfied,

original: cittena, tadāssa paṭhamaṃ akusalacittaṃ uppajjati. Yadā pana mandena samussāhitena,
analyzed: cittena tadā assa paṭhamam akusala cittam uppajjati yadā pana mandena samussāhitena
translated: with a mind that is not aroused by any other means, then the first unprofitable consciousness arises. When he does so with a mind that is aroused by a feeble means,

original: tadā dutiyaṃ. Yadā micchādiṭṭhiṃ apurakkhatvā kevalaṃ haṭṭhatuṭṭho methunaṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: tadā dutiyam yadā micchādiṭṭhim a purakkhatvā kevalam haṭṭha tuṭṭhaḥ methunam dhammaṃ
translated: then the second arises. When he enjoys sensual desires or covets the good fortune of others only with a mind that is pleased and satisfied, without giving wrong view prominence,

original: vā paribhuñjati, parasampattiṃ vā abhijjhāyati, parassa bhaṇḍaṃ vā harati sabhāvatikkheneva
analyzed: vā paribhuñjati para sampattim vā abhijjhāyati parassa bhaṇḍam vā harati
translated: then the third arises. When he misconducts himself in sensual pleasures, or covets the good fortune of others, or steals another’s goods, only with a mind that is pleased and satisfied, with a mind that is not aroused by any other means,

original: anussāhitena cittena, tadā tatiyaṃ. Yadā mandena samussāhitena, tadā catutthaṃ uppajjati.🔽Yadā pana kāmānaṃ vā asampattiṃ āgamma aññesaṃ vā somanassahetūnaṃ abhāvena catūsupi
analyzed: anussāhitena cittena tadā tatiyam yadā mandena samussāhitena tadā catuttham uppajjati  yadā pana kāmānam vā asampattim āgamma aññesam vā somanassa hetūnam abhāvena catūsu pi
translated: When it arises with a mind that is moderately elevated, then the fourth arises.

original: vikappesu somanassarahitā honti, tadā sesāni cattāri upekkhāsahagatāni uppajjantīti.
analyzed: vikappesu somanassa rahitāḥ honti tadā sesāni cattāri upekkhā sahagatāni uppajjanti iti
translated: But when, owing to the absence of any of the four kinds of success in sensual desires or owing to the absence of any other cause for joy, they are devoid of joy in all four cases, then the remaining four kinds that are accompanied by equanimity arise.

analyzed: evam somanassa upekkhā diṭṭhi ppayoga bhedataḥ aṭṭhavidham lobha mūlam veditabbam
translated: So greed as a root of the tree should be understood as of eight kinds according to the difference of joy, equanimity, view, and prompting.🔽But hate as a root of the tree is of one kind according to the kind of object,

original: Dosamūlaṃ pana ekantasavatthukato ekavidhaṃ, asaṅkhārasasaṅkhārabhedato duvidhaṃ
analyzed: dosa mūlam pana ekanta savatthukataḥ ekavidham asaṅkhāra sa saṅkhāra bhedataḥ duvidham
translated: and of two kinds according to the difference of being with or without prompting.🔽It is accompanied by grief and associated with resentment. It is unprompted and prompted.

original: domanassasahagataṃ paṭighasampayuttaṃ asaṅkhāraṃ, sasaṅkhāranti. Assa pana pāṇātipātādīsu
analyzed: domanassa sahagatam paṭigha sampayuttam asaṅkhāram sa saṅkhāranti assa pana pāṇa atipāta ādīsu
translated: But its occurrence should be understood according to the difference of keenness and dullness in the case of killing living things, etc.,

analyzed: tikkha manda ppavatti kāle uppatti veditabbā
translated: and according to the difference of the three doors.

original: Mohamūlampi vicikicchuddhaccayogato duvidhaṃ hoti upekkhāsahagataṃ vicikicchāsampayuttaṃ,
analyzed: moha mūlam pi vicikicchu ddhacca yogataḥ duvidham hoti upekkhā sahagatam vicikicchā sampayuttam
translated: Delusion as a root of the tree is of two kinds according to the difference of uncertainty and agitation. It is accompanied by equanimity and associated with uncertainty,

original: upekkhāsahagataṃ uddhaccasampayuttanti. Tassa asanniṭṭhānavikkhepakālesu pavatti veditabbāti.
analyzed: upekkhā sahagatam uddhacca sampayuttanti tassa asanniṭṭhāna vikkhepa kālesu pavatti veditabbā ti
translated: and with equanimity associated with agitation. It should be understood that it occurs at the time of its non-concentration and distraction.

original: Evaṃ tāva dvādasavidhaṃ akusalacittaṃ veditabbaṃ, sabbaṃ panetaṃ yathānurūpaṃ apāyesu upapattiyā, sugatiyampi dukkhavisesassa abhinipphādakaṃ hoti.
analyzed: evam tāva dvādasavidham akusala cittam veditabbam sabbam pana etam yathānurūpam apāyesu upapattiyā sugatiyam pi dukkha visesassa abhinipphādakam hoti
translated: So firstly, unprofitable consciousness should be understood as of twelve kinds. And all this, according to the kind of rebirth, produces the various kinds of suffering in the unhappy destinies, and in the happy destinies too.

analyzed: dosa mūla vasā duve
translated: Eight rooted in greed, two rooted in hate,

analyzed: moha mūla vasena dve evam dvādasadhā siyum
translated: And two rooted in delusion, so they are of twelve kinds.🔽The unprofitable consciousness called “deceptive”

analyzed: yam vuttam pāpa mānasam
translated: That was said to be in the bad and the bad-and-good,

original: Pāpāpāpappahīnena, taṃ mayā samudāhaṭaṃ.🔽Itaraṃ pana abyākatamavipākārahato ekavidhaṃ hoti, jātibhedato duvidhaṃ vipākacittaṃ🔽kiriyacittanti. Tattha vipākacittaṃ bhūmibhedato catubbidhaṃ kāmāvacaraṃ rūpāvacaraṃ
analyzed: tam mayā  itaram pana ekavidham hoti jāti bhedataḥ duvidham vipāka cittam  kiriya cittanti tattha vipāka cittam bhūmi bhedato catubbidham kāmāvacaram rūpāvacaram
translated: I have explained it thus, as free from bad and good.🔽The other kind, namely, resultant consciousness, is of one kind as not to be abandoned. As to classification by kind, it is twofold, namely, resultant and functional.

original: arūpāvacaraṃ lokuttaranti. Tattha kāmāvacaraṃ duvidhaṃ kusalavipākaṃ akusalavipākanti.
analyzed: arūpāvacaram lokuttaranti tattha kāmāvacaram duvidham kusala vipākam akusala vipākanti
translated: Herein, resultant consciousness is fourfold as to plane, that is to say, it is of the sense sphere, of the fine-material sphere, of the immaterial sphere, and supramundane. Herein, that of the sense sphere is twofold, namely, resultant of profitable and resultant of unprofitable .

analyzed: kusala vipākam duvidham sa hetukam ahetukam ca iti
translated: Resultant consciousness is of two kinds, with root-cause and without root-cause.

original: Tattha sahetukavipākacittaṃ sakakusalaṃ viya somanassupekkhāñāṇappayogabhedato aṭṭhavidhaṃ.
analyzed: tattha sa hetuka vipāka cittam saka kusalam viya somanassa upekkhā ñāṇa ppayoga bhedato aṭṭhavidham
translated: Herein, resultant consciousness with root-cause is of eight kinds, classed according to joy, equanimity, knowledge, and prompting, like profitable consciousness.

original: Seyyathidaṃ – somanassasahagataṃ ñāṇasampayuttaṃ asaṅkhāraṃ, sasaṅkhāraṃ, somanassasahagataṃ
analyzed: seyyathīdam somanassa sahagatam ñāṇa sampayuttam asaṅkhāram sa saṅkhāram somanassa sahagatam
translated: That is to say: accompanied by joy, associated with knowledge, without prompting, with prompting;

original: ñāṇavippayuttaṃ asaṅkhāraṃ, sasaṅkhāraṃ, upekkhāsahagataṃ ñāṇasampayuttaṃ asaṅkhāraṃ,🔽sasaṅkhāraṃ, upekkhāsahagataṃ ñāṇavippayuttaṃ asaṅkhāraṃ, sasaṅkhāranti idaṃ aṭṭhavidhaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇa vippayuttam asaṅkhāram sa saṅkhāram upekkhā sahagatam ñāṇa sampayuttam asaṅkhāram  sa saṅkhāram upekkhā sahagatam ñāṇa vippayuttam asaṅkhāram sa saṅkhāranti idam aṭṭhavidham
translated: accompanied by joy, dissociated from knowledge, without prompting, with prompting; accompanied by equanimity, associated with knowledge, without prompting, with prompting;🔽accompanied by equanimity, dissociated from knowledge, without prompting, with prompting. This is called

analyzed: sa hetuka vipākam nāma
translated: resultant consciousness with root-cause, which is of eight kinds.

original: Yathā panassa kusalaṃ dānādivasena chasu ārammaṇesu pavattati, na idaṃ tathā. Idaṃ
analyzed: yathā panassa kusalam dāna ādi vasena chasu ārammaṇesu pavattati na idam tathā idam
translated: But while the profitable occurs in the six objects beginning with giving, this does not do so. For this occurs

analyzed: hi paṭisandhi bhavaṅga cuti tad ārammaṇa vasena paritta dhamma pariyāpannesu yeva chasu ārammaṇesu
translated: only in the six objects that are limited to the ideas of rebirth-linking, life-continuum, death, and the object of registration.

original: pavattati. Sampayuttadhammānañca visese asatipi ādāsatalādīsu mukhanimittaṃ viya
analyzed: pavattati sampayutta dhammānam ca visese asati pi ādāsa tala ādīsu mukha nimittam viya
translated: And although there is no difference in the associated states, still, as in the case of the reflection of a face in a looking-glass, etc.,

original: nirussāhaṃ vipākaṃ, mukhaṃ viya saussāhaṃ kusalanti veditabbaṃ. Imesaṃ pana vipaccanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: nirussāham vipākam mukham viya saussāham kusalanti veditabbam imesam pana vipaccana ṭhānam
translated: and the result is without urgency, like the face without the smile.🔽The place where these results ripen

original: veditabbaṃ. Imāni hi paṭisandhibhavaṅgacutitadārammaṇāni hutvā vipaccanti.
analyzed: veditabbam imāni hi paṭisandhi bhavaṅga cuti tad ārammaṇāni hutvā vipaccanti
translated: The result is without urgency, like the face without the smile; the profitable is with urgency, like the face with the smile. The place where they ripen should be understood as follows. For these are ripened as rebirth-linking, life-continuum, death, and object-determinations.

original: Kāmāvacaradevānaṃ, manussānaṃ ime pana;🔽Duhetukatihetūnaṃ, bhavanti paṭisandhiyo.🔽Tato pavattiyaṃ hutvā, bhavaṅgaṃ yāvatāyukaṃ;
analyzed: kāmāvacara devānam manussānam ime pana  bhavanti paṭisandhiyaḥ  tatas pavattiyam hutvā bhavaṅgam yāvatāyukam
translated: In the case of gods and men in the sense-desire world,🔽These are the kinds of rebirth-linking That have two roots and have three roots.🔽Then they are the life-continuum As long as life lasts, in occurrence;

analyzed: balava ārammaṇe hutvā tad ārammaṇam eva ca
translated: And when there is a strong objective field, They are the object-determinations.

analyzed: tatas maraṇa kālasmin cuti hutvā pavattare
translated: Then at the time of death They are death and reappearance;

analyzed: evam catūsu ṭhānesu vipaccanti iti niddise
translated: Thus they ripen in four places, As shown by the exposition.

analyzed: mahā pākā samāḥ vinā
translated: But they are not the same as the great resultants, Which are only in the fine-material sphere,

analyzed: kamma dvāram ca kammañca puññānam kriya vatthukam
translated: And they are not the same as the meritorious, Which have the door of action and action for their basis.

analyzed: a viññatti janattā hi a vipāka sabhāvataḥ
translated: For they are not intimation, And they are not by nature resultants,

original: Appavattanato ceva, pākā puññehi no samā.
analyzed: a pavattanataḥ ca iva pākā puññehi no samā
translated: And they do not occur in the past, So the meritorious are not the same as the resultants.

analyzed: paritta ārammaṇa ttā hi tesam ekantato pana
translated: But because their object is limited, They are in one part the same as the latter.

analyzed: tesu na jāyanti
translated: But in the case of the latter, Compassion and gladness are never found.

original: Tathā viratiyo tisso, na panetesu jāyare;
analyzed: tathā viratiyaḥ tissaḥ na pana etesu jāyare
translated: But these are not found in them.🔽Five training precepts are declared,

original: Pañca sikkhāpadā vuttā, kusalāti hi satthunā.🔽Tathādhipatinopettha, na santīti viniddise;
analyzed: pañca sikkhāpadā vuttā kusalā ati hi satthunā  tathā adhipatinā upettha na santi iti viniddise
translated: And also profitable, by the wise.🔽So too, the dominants are not found here,

analyzed: chanda ādīni dhuram katvā anuppajjanataḥ pana
translated: Because they do not arise, making will, etc., their domain.

analyzed: asaṅkhāra sasaṅkhāra vidhānam pana puññato
translated: But the kinds of merit that are without-determining, with-determining,🔽Should be known by the wise from the conditions,

original: Ñeyyaṃ paccayato ceva, vipākesu ca viññunā.🔽Hīnādīnaṃ vipākattā, puññānaṃ puññavādinā;
analyzed: ñeyyam paccayato ca iva vipākesu ca viññunā  hīna ādīnam vipāka ttā puññānam puñña vādinā
translated: And also from the ripening.🔽Because of the inferior, etc., ripening of the kinds of merit,🔽The inferior, etc., are demonstrated

analyzed: hīna ādayaḥ bhavanti iti vipākā paridīpitā
translated: As the ripening by the expounders of merit.

analyzed: idam aṭṭhavidham cittam ekantena sa vatthukam
translated: This eightfold consciousness🔽Arises in the sense-desire world,

analyzed: jāyate kāma lokasmim na pana aññattha jāyate
translated: But not in any other world.

analyzed: evam tāva sa hetuka vipāka cittam veditabbam
translated: So firstly consciousness with root-cause should be understood.

original: Ahetukavipākacittaṃ pana alobhādihetuvirahitaṃ upekkhāsahagataṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, upekkhāsahagataṃ
analyzed: ahetuka vipāka cittam pana alobha ādi hetu virahitam upekkhā sahagatam cakkhu viññāṇam upekkhā sahagatam
translated: But as to consciousness without root-cause, that is eye-consciousness accompanied by equanimity, which is devoid of the root-cause of non-greed, etc.,🔽ear-consciousness accompanied by equanimity,

original: sotaviññāṇaṃ, upekkhāsahagataṃ ghānaviññāṇaṃ, upekkhāsahagataṃ jivhāviññāṇaṃ, sukhasahagataṃ
analyzed: sota viññāṇam upekkhā sahagatam ghāna viññāṇam upekkhā sahagatam jivhā viññāṇam sukha sahagatam
translated: nose-consciousness accompanied by equanimity, tongue-consciousness accompanied by pleasure,

analyzed: kāya viññāṇam upekkhā sahagatam ahetuka manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchanam somanassa sahagatam
translated: Body-consciousness, the receiving of the mind-element accompanied by equanimity and without root-cause, the receiving of the mind-element accompanied by joy and without root-cause,

analyzed: ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu santīraṇam upekkhā sahagatam ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu santīraṇam ti
translated: Body-consciousness, and the receiving of the mind-element accompanied by equanimity and without root-cause, and the investigating of the mind-consciousness-element accompanied by joy and without root-cause, and the investigating of the mind-consciousness-element accompanied by equanimity and without root-cause.

analyzed: idam pana aṭṭhavidham ahetuka vipāka cittam nāma
translated: This is called the eightfold resultant consciousness without root-cause.

original: Idaṃ pana aṭṭhavidhaṃ niyatavatthukato ekavidhaṃ, niyatāniyatārammaṇato duvidhaṃ.🔽Tattha viññāṇapañcakaṃ niyatārammaṇaṃ, sesattayaṃ aniyatārammaṇaṃ. Sukhasomanassupekkhāvedanāyogato
analyzed: idam pana aṭṭhavidham niyata vatthukataḥ ekavidham niyata aniyata ārammaṇataḥ duvidham  tattha viññāṇa pañcakam niyata ārammaṇam sesa ttayam aniyata ārammaṇam sukha so manas supekkhā vedanā yogato
translated: This eightfold consciousness without root-cause is of one kind as to its fixed basis, and of two kinds as to its fixed and unfixed object.🔽Herein, the fivefold consciousness has a fixed object, and the remaining three have an unfixed object. It is of three kinds as to its association with the feelings of pleasure, joy, and equanimity.

original: tividhaṃ. Tattha sukhasahagataṃ kāyaviññāṇaṃ, dviṭṭhānikaṃ santīraṇaṃ somanassupekkhāyuttaṃ,
analyzed: tividham tattha sukha sahagatam kāya viññāṇam dvi ṭṭhānikam santīraṇam somanassa upekkhā yuttam
translated: Herein, body-consciousness accompanied by pleasure, and the investigating of the two planes accompanied by joy and equanimity,

analyzed: sesam upekkhā yuttam ti  diṭṭha ārammaṇa suta ārammaṇa muta ārammaṇa diṭṭha suta muta ārammaṇa diṭṭha suta muta viññāta ārammaṇa vasena
translated: and the rest accompanied by equanimity.🔽It is of five kinds as to its object being seen, heard, sensed, cognized, seen-and-cognized, heard-and-cognized, sensed-and-cognized.

original: pañcavidhaṃ. Tattha diṭṭhārammaṇaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, sutārammaṇaṃ sotaviññāṇaṃ, mutārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: pañcavidham tattha diṭṭha ārammaṇam cakkhu viññāṇam suta ārammaṇam sota viññāṇam muta ārammaṇam
translated: Herein, eye-consciousness has an object that is seen; ear-consciousness has an object that is heard;

analyzed: ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇa ttayam diṭṭha suta muta ārammaṇam manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchanam diṭṭha suta muta viññāta ārammaṇam
translated: The three, eye-, ear-, and nose-consciousness, have as their object what is visible, sound, and odour respectively. Tongue-consciousness has as its object flavour. Body-consciousness has as its object tangible datum. Mind-element has as its object what is visible, etc., according to the mode of the door of consciousness. Mind-consciousness-element has as its object the six objects.

original: sesamanoviññāṇadhātudvayanti.🔽Vatthuto chabbidhaṃ. Kathaṃ? Cakkhuviññāṇassa cakkhumeva vatthu, tathā sotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇānaṃ sotaghānajivhākāyavatthu, avasesattayassa hadayavatthumevāti.
analyzed: sesa manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu dvayanti  vatthutaḥ chabbidham katham cakkhu viññāṇassa cakkhum eva vatthu tathā sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇānam sota ghāna jivhā kāya vatthu avasesa ttayassa hadaya vatthum eva ati
translated: The remaining two kinds of mind-consciousness-element have as their object the six objects.🔽According to physical basis, it is sixfold. How? The eye-door is the physical basis of eye-consciousness. Similarly, the ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-doors are the physical bases of ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-consciousness respectively. The heart-basis is the physical basis of the remaining seven.

original: Ārammaṇato sattavidhaṃ hoti. Kathaṃ? Rūpārammaṇameva cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, tathā saddagandharasaphoṭṭhabbārammaṇāni
analyzed: ārammaṇato sattavidham hoti katham rūpa ārammaṇam eva cakkhu viññāṇam tathā sadda gandha rasa phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇāni
translated: According to object, it is sevenfold. How? Eye-consciousness has only visible datum as its object. Similarly, ear-, nose-, tongue-, and body-consciousness have sound, odour, flavour, and tangible datum respectively as their objects.

original: paṭipāṭiyā sotaghānajivhākāyaviññāṇāni, rūpādipañcārammaṇā manodhātu, sesamanoviññāṇadhātudvayaṃ chaḷārammaṇanti.
analyzed: paṭipāṭiyā sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇāni rūpa ādi pañca ārammaṇā manaḥ dhātu sesa manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu dvayam chaṣ ārammaṇanti
translated: Mind-element has as its object the five beginning with visible datum. The two kinds of mind-consciousness-element have as their objects the six objects.

original: Taṃ sabbaṃ pana ahetukavipākacittaṃ kiccato aṭṭhavidhaṃ hoti. Kathaṃ? Dassanakiccaṃ cakkhuviññāṇaṃ, savanaghāyanasāyanaphusanasampaṭicchanasantīraṇatadārammaṇakiccāni avasesāni.
analyzed: tat sabbam pana ahetuka vipāka cittam kiccataḥ aṭṭhavidham hoti katham dassana kiccam cakkhu viññāṇam savana ghāyana sāyana phusana sampaṭicchana santīraṇa tad ārammaṇa kiccāni avasesāni
translated: But all that resultant consciousness without root-cause is eightfold according to function. How? Eye-consciousness has the function of seeing; the remaining kinds have the functions of receiving, and so on.

original: Tattha cakkhuto pavattaṃ viññāṇaṃ, cakkhumhi sannissitaṃ viññāṇanti vā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: tattha cakkhutaḥ pavattam viññāṇam cakkhumhi sannissitam viññāṇanti vā cakkhu viññāṇam
translated: Herein, the consciousness that occurs with the eye as its physical basis is eye-consciousness, or it is consciousness of visible data.

analyzed: tathā sota viññāṇa ādīni tattha cakkhu sannissita rūpa vijānana lakkhaṇam cakkhu viññāṇam
translated: So too with ear-consciousness, and so on. Herein, the characteristic of eye-consciousness is the act of experiencing visible data;

analyzed: rūpa matta ārammaṇa rasam rūpa abhimukha bhāva paccupaṭṭhānam rūpa ārammaṇāya kiriyā manaḥ dhātuyā
translated: its function is to impinge on visible data; its manifestation is the appearance as visible data; its proximate cause is the inconstant eye sensitivity. So too with ear-consciousness, and so on.

analyzed: apagama padaṭṭhānam tathā sota ghāna jivhā kāya viññāṇāni sota ādi sannissita sadda ādi vijānana lakkhaṇāni
translated: Herein, the characteristic of ear-consciousness is the act of experiencing sounds;

analyzed: sadda ādimatta ārammaṇa rasāni sadda ādīsu abhimukha bhāva paccupaṭṭhānāni sadda ādi ārammaṇānam
translated: its function is to impinge on sounds; its manifestation is the appearance as sounds; its proximate cause is the inconstant ear sensitivity.

analyzed: kiriyā manaḥ dhātūnam apagama padaṭṭhānāni manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchanam pana cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam
translated: The receiving of the mind element has the characteristic of receiving visible data, etc., after eye-consciousness, etc.;

analyzed: anantarā rūpa ādi vijānana lakkhaṇam rūpa ādi sampaṭicchana rasam tathābhāva paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: its function is to receive visible data, etc.; its manifestation is the assuming of the state of being a visible-data receiver, etc.;

analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam apagama padaṭṭhānam
translated: it has the disappearance of eye-consciousness, etc., as its proximate cause.

original: Sesā pana dve ahetukamanoviññāṇadhātuyo chaḷārammaṇavijānanalakkhaṇā, santīraṇādirasā,
analyzed: sesā pana dve ahetuka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātuyo chaṣ ārammaṇa vijānana lakkhaṇā santi īraṇa ādi rasā
translated: The other two kinds of unprofitable mind-consciousness element and the six kinds of resultant mind-element have the characteristic of cognizing the six kinds of objects; their function is investigating, etc.;

original: tathābhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, hadayavatthupadaṭṭhānāti veditabbā. Tattha paṭhamā ekantamiṭṭhārammaṇe🔽pavattisabbhāvato somanassayuttāva hutvā pañcadvāre santīraṇakiccaṃ sādhayamānā pañcasu🔽dvāresu ṭhatvā vipaccati, chasu pana dvāresu balavārammaṇe tadārammaṇaṃ hutvā vipaccati.
analyzed: tathābhāva paccupaṭṭhānā hadaya vatthu padaṭṭhānā ti veditabbā tattha paṭhamā ekantam iṭṭha ārammaṇe  pavatti sabbhāvato hutvā pañca dvāre santīraṇa kiccam sādhayamānā pañcasu  dvāresu ṭhatvā vipaccati chasu pana dvāresu balava ārammaṇe tad ārammaṇam hutvā vipaccati
translated: their manifestation is the assuming of the state of being an investigator, etc.; their proximate cause is the heart-basis.🔽Herein, the first, which occurs only in regard to a desirable object, is accompanied by joy because it is associated with joy since it occurs in one way only, and it comes to maturity by standing in the five doors and accomplishing the function of investigating, but when the object is a powerful one it comes to maturity by standing in the six doors and being that object.

original: Dutiyā pana iṭṭhamajjhattārammaṇe pavattisabbhāvato upekkhāsahagatā hutvā santīraṇatadārammaṇapaṭisandhibhavaṅgacutivasena
analyzed: dutiyā pana iṭṭha majjhatta ārammaṇe pavatti sabbhāvataḥ upekkhā sahagatā hutvā santi īraṇa tad ārammaṇa paṭisandhi bhavaṅga cuti vasena
translated: The second, which occurs in regard to a desirable or neutral object, is accompanied by equanimity because it occurs in two ways, and it comes to maturity as investigation, as the object of that, and as rebirth-linking, life-continuum, and death.

original: pavattanato pañcasu ṭhānesu vipaccati. Kathaṃ? Manussaloke tāva jaccandhajaccabadhirajaccajaḷajaccummattakapaṇḍakaubhatobyañjananapuṃsakādīnaṃ
analyzed: pavattanato pañcasu ṭhānesu vipaccati katham manussa loke tāva jaccandha jacca badhira jacca jaḷa jaccummattaka paṇḍa kaubhata ubyañjana napuṃsaka ādīnam
translated: It ripens in five instances by way of occurrence. How? In the human world, firstly, at the time of taking rebirth-linking, it ripens as rebirth-linking in those who are blind from birth, deaf from birth, blind and deaf, dumb, witless, hermaphrodites, eunuchs, and so on.

original: paṭisandhiggahaṇakāle paṭisandhi hutvā vipaccati. Paṭisandhiyā vītivattāya pavattiyaṃ
analyzed: paṭisandhi ggahaṇa kāle paṭisandhi hutvā vipaccati paṭisandhiyā vītivattāya pavattiyam
translated: After the rebirth-linking has ceased, it ripens as the life-continuum for as long as life lasts.

original: yāvatāyukaṃ bhavaṅgaṃ hutvā vipaccati. Iṭṭhamajjhatte pañcārammaṇavīthiyā santīraṇaṃ
analyzed: yāvatāyukam bhavaṅgam hutvā vipaccati iṭṭha majjhatte pañca ārammaṇa vīthiyā santīraṇam
translated: It ripens as the registration of the five-door adverting in the case of a desirable or undesirable object,

original: hutvā, balavārammaṇe chadvāre tadārammaṇaṃ hutvā, maraṇakāle cuti hutvāti imesu pana
analyzed: hutvā balava ārammaṇe cha dvāre tad ārammaṇam hutvā maraṇa kāle cuti hutvā ati imesu pana
translated: and it ripens as the adverting of the six doors in the case of a very desirable or very undesirable object, and at the time of death it ripens as death. So it ripens in these five instances.

original: pañcasu ṭhānesu vipaccatīti. Evaṃ tāva ahetukavipākacittāni veditabbāni.
analyzed: pañcasu ṭhānesu vipaccati iti evam tāva ahetuka vipāka cittāni veditabbāni

original: dutiyaṃ, pītisukhacittekaggatāsampayuttaṃ tatiyaṃ, sukhacittekaggatāsampayuttaṃ catutthaṃ,🔽upekkhācittekaggatāsampayuttaṃ pañcamanti imāni pañcapi rūpāvacaravipākacittāni upapattiyaṃ
analyzed: dutiyam pīti sukha citta ekagga tā sampayuttam tatiyam sukha citta ekagga tā sampayuttam catuttham  upekkhā citta ekagga tā sampayuttam imāni pañca api rūpāvacara vipāka cittāni

translated: How? Associated with the perception of the base consisting of boundless space, associated with the perception of the base consisting of boundless consciousness, associated with the perception of the base consisting of nothingness,

analyzed: sesam sabbam ca sesena kusalena samam matam
translated: Equal to the rest of the profitable.

analyzed: evam rūpāvacara arūpāvacara vipākā veditabbā
translated: So should be understood the resultant consciousness of the fine-material sphere and the immaterial sphere.

analyzed: idāni lokuttara vipāka cittāni honti tāni catu magga yutta citta phalattā catubbidhāni

analyzed: cittassa ekagga bhāvaḥ citta ekagga tā samādhissa etam nāmam saḥ a visāra lakkhaṇaḥ a vikkhepa lakkhaṇaḥ

translated: and it is the consolidating essence of what is associated with it, like water of bath-powder rubbed into a lather. It is the proximate cause for the attainment of cessation.

analyzed: visesataḥ sukha padaṭṭhāno  saddahanti etāya sayam vā saddahati saddahana mattam eva vai esā ati saddhā sā pana isā

original: Saranti etāya, sayaṃ vā sarati, saraṇamattameva vā esāti sati. Sā apilāpanalakkhaṇā, asammosarasā, ārakkhapaccupaṭṭhānā, thirasaññāpadaṭṭhānā.

translated: It is mindfulness because of remembering, or because of causing the mind to be present, or because of being the state of presence of mind. Its characteristic is non-forgetting. Its function is not to lose an object. It is manifested as non-distraction. Its proximate cause is an object that is being investigated.

original: Vīrabhāvo vīriyaṃ. Vīrānaṃ vā kammaṃ vīriyaṃ. Taṃ panetaṃ ussāhanalakkhaṇaṃ, sahajātānaṃ upatthambhanarasaṃ, asaṃsīdanabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, saṃvegapadaṭṭhānaṃ.

translated: It is energy because of energizing, or because of bearing up, or because of exertion. Its characteristic is that of striving. Its function is to consolidate what is associated with it. It is manifested as non-lapsing. Its proximate cause is an inspiring object.

original: Pajānātīti paññā. Sā panesā vijānanalakkhaṇā, visayobhāsanarasā padīpo viya, asammohapaccupaṭṭhānā araññagatasudesako viya.
analyzed: pajānāti iti paññā sā pana isā vijānana lakkhaṇā visaya ubhāsana rasā padīpaḥ viya asammoha paccupaṭṭhānā arañña gata sudesakaḥ viya
translated: Understanding is the act of understanding. It has the characteristic of knowing. Its function is to illuminate an objective field, like a lamp. It is manifested as non-delusion, like a guide in a forest.

original: Jīvanti tena taṃsampayuttadhammāti jīvitaṃ. Taṃ pana attanā avinibbhuttānaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: jīvanti tena tad sampayutta dhammā ati jīvitam tam pana attanā a vinibbhuttānam dhammānam
translated: Life is that by means of which the things associated with it live. It has the characteristic of maintaining those things that are not themselves the cause of their own dissolution.

original: anupālanalakkhaṇaṃ, tesaṃ pavattanarasaṃ, tesaṃyeva ṭhapanapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, yāpayitabbadhammapadaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: anupālana lakkhaṇam tesam pavattana rasam tesam yeva ṭhapana paccupaṭṭhānam yāpayitabba dhamma padaṭṭhānam
translated: Its function is to continue them. It is manifested as their establishment. Its proximate cause is the things that are to be maintained.

original: Santepi ca tesaṃ anupālanalakkhaṇādimhi vidhāne atthikkhaṇeyeva taṃ te dhamme anupāleti🔽udakaṃ viya uppalādīni, yathāsakaṃ paccayuppannepi ca dhamme anupāleti dhāti viya
analyzed: sante api ca tesam anupālana lakkhaṇa ādimhi vidhāne atthi kkhaṇe iva tam te dhamme anupāleti  udakam viya uppala ādīni yathāsakam paccaya uppanne pi ca dhamme anupāleti dhāti viya
translated: And although the function of maintaining is common to the four primary elements, still the life faculty maintains only those things associated with itself,🔽like water the lotuses, etc., and it maintains them only as long as they are about to arise,

original: kumāraṃ, sayaṃpavattitadhammasambandheneva pavattati niyāmako viya, na bhaṅgato uddhaṃ
analyzed: kumāram sayaṃpavattita dhamma sambandhena iva pavattati niyāmakaḥ viya na bhaṅgataḥ uddham
translated: like a nurse the prince, and it occurs only in association with the things that it maintains, like a leader. It does not cause them to occur after their dissolution,

original: pavattayati attano ca pavattayitabbānañca abhāvā, na bhaṅgakkhaṇe ṭhapeti sayaṃ bhijjamānattā
analyzed: pavattayati ca pavattayitabbānam ca abhāvā na bhaṅga kkhaṇe ṭhapeti sayam bhijjamāna ttā
translated: because there is no further occurrence of itself or of those things that have occurred. It does not establish them at the moment of their dissolution,🔽because it itself is dissolving.

analyzed: khīyamānaḥ viya
translated: like the flame of a lamp that is running out of oil.

original: Na lubbhanti tena, sayaṃ vā na lubbhati, alubbhanamattameva vā tanti alobho. So ārammaṇe
analyzed: na lubbhanti tena sayam vā na lubbhati alubbhana mattam eva vā alobho so ārammaṇe
translated: It is non-greed because of non-greediness towards that, or because of non-greediness in oneself, or because of mere non-greediness. Its characteristic is non-attachment to an object,

original: cittassa alaggabhāvalakkhaṇo kamaladale jalabindu viya, apariggaharaso muttabhikkhu🔽viya, anallīnabhāvapaccupaṭṭhāno asucimhi patitapuriso viya.
analyzed: cittassa a lagga bhāva lakkhaṇaḥ kamala dale jala bindu viya a pariggaha rasaḥ mutta bhikkhu  viya an allīna bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno asucimhi patita puriso viya
translated: like a drop of water on a lotus leaf. Its function is to reject, like a contented bhikkhu. It is manifested as non-addiction, like a man who has fallen into filth.

original: Na dussanti tena, sayaṃ vā na dussati, adussanamattameva vā tanti adoso. So acaṇḍikkalakkhaṇo,🔽avirodhalakkhaṇo vā anukūlamitto viya, āghātavinayanaraso, pariḷāhavinayanaraso vā
analyzed: na dussanti tena sayam vā na dussati a dussana mattam eva vā a doso saḥ a caṇḍikka lakkhaṇo  avirodha lakkhaṇo vā anukūla mittaḥ viya āghāta vinayana raso pariḷāha vinayana rasaḥ vā
translated: It is non-hate because of non-hateness towards that, or because of non-hateness in oneself, or because of mere non-hateness. Its characteristic is non-aversion,

original: candanaṃ viya, sommabhāvapaccupaṭṭhāno puṇṇacando viya.🔽Kāyaduccaritādīhi hirīyatīti hirī. Lajjāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tehiyeva ottappatīti ottappaṃ.
analyzed: candanam viya somma bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno puṇṇa candaḥ viya  kāya duccarita ādīhi hirīyati iti hirī adhivacanam ottappati iti ottappam
translated: like a friendly disposition. Its function is to remove annoyance, or its function is to remove fever, like sandalwood. It is manifested as amiability, like the full moon.🔽It is conscience because of being ashamed of bodily misconduct, etc.,🔽or because of being ashamed of evil-doing. It is shame, this is a term for bashfulness. It is shame because of being abashed by bodily misconduct, etc., or because of being abashed by evil-doing.

original: Pāpato ubbegassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tattha pāpato jigucchanalakkhaṇā hirī, ottāsalakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: pāpataḥ ubbegassa itam adhivacanam tattha pāpataḥ jigucchana lakkhaṇā hirī ottāsa lakkhaṇam
translated: Herein, conscience has the characteristic of shrinking from wrongdoing. Its function is to avoid evil. It is manifested as respect. Its proximate cause is the blameworthy nature of evil-doing.

original: ottappaṃ. Ubhopi pāpānaṃ akaraṇarasā, pāpato saṅkocanapaccupaṭṭhānā, attagāravaparagāravapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: uttappam ubho pi pāpānam a karaṇa rasā pāpataḥ saṅkocana paccupaṭṭhānā atta gārava para gārava padaṭṭhānā
translated: Shame is the opposite of shamelessness. Both have the characteristic of non-doing of evil; their function is to shrink from evil; they are manifested as self-respect and respect for others; their proximate cause is self-respect and respect for others.

original: Ime dhammā lokapālāti daṭṭhabbā.🔽Kāyapassambhanaṃ kāyapassaddhi. Cittapassambhanaṃ cittapassaddhi. Kāyoti cettha vedanādayo
analyzed: ime dhammā lokapālā ti daṭṭhabbā  kāya passambhanam kāya passaddhi citta passambhanam citta passaddhi kāyo ti ca ittha vedanā ādayaḥ
translated: These are the states that should be regarded as world-guardians.🔽Tranquillization of the body is bodily tranquillity. Tranquillization of cognizance is cognizance tranquillity. Herein, “body” is the three aggregates associated with the three sensitive faculties.

original: tayo khandhā. Ubhopi panetā ekato hutvā kāyacittadarathavūpasamalakkhaṇā, kāyacittadarathanimmadanarasā,
analyzed: tayo khandhāḥ ubho pi panetā ekatas hutvā kāya cit tada ratha vūpasama lakkhaṇā kāya cit tada ratha nimmadana rasā
translated: Both have the characteristic of quieting restlessness of body and cognizance; their function is to dispel restlessness of body and cognizance;

analyzed: kāya cittānam a paripphandana sīti bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā kāya citta padaṭṭhānā kāya cittānam
translated: they are manifested as unagitated coolness of body and cognizance; their proximate cause is body and cognizance;

original: avūpasamatāuddhaccādikilesappaṭipakkhabhūtāti veditabbā.🔽Kāyalahubhāvo kāyalahutā. Cittalahubhāvo cittalahutā. Kāyacittānaṃ garubhāvavūpasamalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: a vūpasama tā auddhacca ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati veditabbā  kāya lahu bhāvaḥ kāya lahu tā citta lahu bhāvaḥ citta lahu tā kāya cittānam garu bhāva vūpasama lakkhaṇā
translated: they should be understood as the opposite of the defilements of agitation, etc., in body and cognizance.🔽Lightness of the body is bodily lightness. Lightness of cognizance is cognizance lightness. They have the characteristic of quieting heaviness of body and cognizance;

analyzed: kāya citta garu bhāva nimmadana rasā kāya cittānam adandha tā paccupaṭṭhānā kāya citta padaṭṭhānā
translated: their function is to dispel heaviness of body and cognizance; they are manifested as unrigidness of body and cognizance; their proximate cause is body and cognizance;

analyzed: kāya cittānam veditabbā
translated: It should be understood as the opposite of the defilements that cause heaviness, stiffness, unfitness, and torpor in the body and the mind.

original: Kāyamudubhāvo kāyamudutā. Cittamudubhāvo cittamudutā. Kāyacittānaṃ thaddhabhāvavūpasamalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: kāya mudu bhāvaḥ kāya mudu tā citta mudu bhāvaḥ citta mudu tā kāya cittānam thaddha bhāva vūpasama lakkhaṇā
translated: Suppleness of the body is bodily flexibility; suppleness of the mind is mental flexibility. Their characteristic is the allaying of stiffness in the body and the mind.

analyzed: kāya cittānam thaddha bhāva nimmadana rasā appaṭighāta paccupaṭṭhānā kāya citta padaṭṭhānā
translated: Their function is to remove the unfitness of the body and the mind. They are manifested as non-resistance. Their proximate causes are the body and the mind.

analyzed: kāya cittānam thaddha bhāva kara diṭṭhi māna ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati veditabbā
translated: They should be understood as the opposite of the defilements that cause stiffness in the body and the mind, such as wrong view and conceit.

original: Kāyakammaññabhāvo kāyakammaññatā. Cittakammaññabhāvo cittakammaññatā. Kāyacittānaṃ🔽akammaññabhāvavūpasamalakkhaṇā, kāyacittānaṃ akammaññabhāvanimmadanarasā, kāyacittānaṃ
analyzed: kāya kammañña bhāvaḥ kāya kammañña tā citta kammañña bhāvaḥ citta kammañña tā kāya cittānam  a kammañña bhāva vūpasama lakkhaṇā kāya cittānaṃ a kammañña bhāva nimmadana rasā kāya cittānaṃ
translated: Workableness of the body is bodily workableness; workableness of the mind is mental workableness.🔽Their characteristic is the allaying of unworkableness in the body and the mind. Their function is to remove unworkableness in the body and the mind. They are manifested as the excellence of the body and the mind’s being fit for work.

analyzed: ārammaṇa karaṇa sampatti paccupaṭṭhānā kāya citta padaṭṭhānam kāya cittānam akammañña bhāva kara avasesa nīvaraṇa ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati veditabbā
translated: Their proximate cause is the body and the mind. They should be understood as the opposite of the defilements that cause unworkableness in the body and the mind, such as the remaining hindrances.

original: Kāyapāguññabhāvo kāyapāguññatā. Cittapāguññabhāvo cittapāguññatā. Kāyacittānaṃ agelaññabhāvalakkhaṇā,🔽kāyacittānaṃ gelaññanimmadanarasā, nirādīnavapaccupaṭṭhānā, kāyacittapadaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: kāya pāguñña bhāvaḥ kāya pāguñña tā citta pāguñña bhāvaḥ citta pāguñña tā kāya cittānaṃ a gelañña bhāva lakkhaṇā  kāya cittānam gelañña nimmadana rasāḥ nirādīnava paccupaṭṭhānā kāya citta padaṭṭhānā
translated: The state of being a bodily affliction is bodily affliction. The state of being a mental affliction is mental affliction. They have the characteristic of non-limpidity of body and mind.🔽Their function is to remove limpidity from body and mind. They are manifested as non-restraint.

analyzed: kāya cittānam gelañña bhāva kara assaddha ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: Their proximate causes are body and mind. They should be regarded as the opposites of the faith, etc., that cause limpidity of body and mind.

original: Kāyassa ujukabhāvo kāyujukatā. Cittassa ujukabhāvo cittujukatā. Kāyacittānaṃ akuṭilabhāvalakkhaṇā,
analyzed: kāyassa ujuka bhāvo kāya ujuka tā cittassa ujuka bhāvo citta ujuka tā kāya cittānaṃ akuṭila bhāva lakkhaṇā
translated: The state of being straight in the body is bodily straightforwardness. The state of being straight in the mind is mental straightforwardness. They have the characteristic of non-crookedness of body and mind.

original: kāyacittānaṃ ajjavalakkhaṇā vā, kāyacittānaṃ kuṭilabhāvanimmadanarasā, ajimhatāpaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: kāya cittānam vā kāya cittānam kuṭila bhāva nimmadana rasāḥ a jimha tā paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: Or they have the characteristic of frankness of body and mind. Their function is to remove crookedness from body and mind. They are manifested as non-guile.

analyzed: kāya citta padaṭṭhānā kāya cittānam kuṭila bhāva kara māyā sāṭheyya ādi kilesa paṭipakkha bhūtā ati daṭṭhabbā
translated: Their proximate causes are body and mind. They should be regarded as the opposites of the deceptions, craftiness, etc., that cause crookedness of body and mind.

original: Chandoti kattukamyatāyetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tasmā so kattukamyatālakkhaṇo chando, ārammaṇapariyesanaraso, ārammaṇena atthikatāpaccupaṭṭhāno, tadevassa padaṭṭhāno.🔽Adhimuccanaṃ adhimokkho. So sanniṭṭhānalakkhaṇo, asaṃsappanaraso, nicchayapaccupaṭṭhāno, sanniṭṭheyyadhammapadaṭṭhāno, ārammaṇe niccalabhāvena indakhīlo viya daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: chandaḥ ti adhivacanam tasmā saḥ kattu kamya tā lakkhaṇaḥ chandaḥ ārammaṇa pariyesana rasaḥ ārammaṇena atthika tā paccupaṭṭhāno tad evassa padaṭṭhāno  adhimuccanam adhimokkhaḥ so sanniṭṭhāna lakkhaṇaḥ a saṃsappana rasaḥ nicchaya paccupaṭṭhānaḥ sanniṭṭheyya dhamma padaṭṭhānaḥ ārammaṇe niccala bhāvena inda khīlaḥ viya daṭṭhabbo
translated: “Desire” is a term for the wish to act. Consequently, desire has the characteristic of wishing to act. Its function is to seek an object. It is manifested as the desire for an object. Its proximate cause is that same object.🔽“Resolve” is the resolving of a doubt. It has the characteristic of certainty. Its function is not to waver. It is manifested as steadiness. Its proximate cause is the thing to be resolved upon. It should be regarded as like an indakhīla stake in that it is unshakable with regard to its object.

original: Tesu tesu dhammesu majjhattabhāvo tatramajjhattatā. Sā cittacetasikānaṃ samavāhitalakkhaṇā, ūnādhikatānivāraṇarasā, pakkhapātupacchedanarasā vā, majjhattabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: tesu tesu dhammesu majjhatta bhāvo tatra majjhatta tā sā citta cetasikānam samavāhita lakkhaṇā ūna adhika tā nivāraṇa rasā pakkhapāta upacchedana rasā vā majjhatta bhāva paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: “Equanimity” is the state of neutrality towards those things that are neither to be done nor to be avoided. It has the characteristic of neutrality towards the mental factors of cognizance and conscious experience. Its function is to prevent excess. Its manifestation is neutrality.

original: Kiriyā kāro, manasmiṃ kāro manasikāro. Purimamanato visadisaṃ manaṃ karotīti ca manasikāro.
analyzed: kiriyā kāraḥ manasmim kāraḥ manasikāraḥ purima manataḥ visadisam manam karoti iti ca manasikāraḥ
translated: “Attention” is the act of attending. It is the act of attending to in the mind. It is also attention because it makes the mind distinct by being unlike the preceding attention.

original: Svāyaṃ ārammaṇapaṭipādako, vīthipaṭipādako, javanapaṭipādakoti tippakāro. Tattha
analyzed: ārammaṇa paṭipādakaḥ vīthi paṭipādakaḥ javana paṭipādakaḥ ti tippakāro tattha
translated: It is of three kinds as the attention that lays hold of an object, the attention that lays hold of a course, and the attention that lays hold of impulsion. Herein:

original: ārammaṇapaṭipādako manasmiṃ kāro manasikāro. So sāraṇalakkhaṇo, sampayuttānaṃ ārammaṇe
analyzed: ārammaṇa paṭipādakaḥ manasmim kāraḥ manasikāro so sāraṇa lakkhaṇo sampayuttānam ārammaṇe
translated: The function of directing the mind onto an object is the act of giving attention. It has the characteristic of inclining towards an object.

analyzed: saṃyojana rasaḥ ārammaṇa abhimukha bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno ārammaṇa padaṭṭhāno saṅkhāra kkhandha pariyāpanno
translated: Its manifestation is the arousing of associated states towards the object. Its footing is the object. It is included in the aggregate of volitional formations.

original: ārammaṇapaṭipādakattena sampayuttānaṃ sārathī viya daṭṭhabbo. Vīthipaṭipādakoti pañcadvārāvajjanassetaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇa paṭipādaka ttena sampayuttānam sārathī viya daṭṭhabbaḥ vīthi paṭipādakaḥ ti pañca dvāra āvajjanassa etam
translated: It should be regarded as the charioteer of the associated states in that it directs them onto the object. The function of directing onto a cognitive series is a term for adverting at the five doors.

original: adhivacanaṃ, javanapaṭipādakoti manodvārāvajjanassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ, na te idha adhippetā.🔽Karuṇāti paradukkhe sati sādhūnaṃ hadayakampanaṃ karotīti karuṇā, kināti vināseti🔽vā paradukkhanti karuṇā. Sā paradukkhāpanayanākārappavattilakkhaṇā, paradukkhāsahanarasā,
analyzed: adhivacanam javana paṭipādakaḥ ti adhivacanam na te idha adhippetā  karuṇā ati para dukkhe sati sādhūnam hadaya kampanam karoti iti karuṇā  vā para dukkhanti karuṇā sā para dukkha apanayana ākāra ppavatti lakkhaṇā para dukkha asahana rasā
translated: The function of directing onto impulsion is a term for adverting at the mind door. But these are not intended here.🔽Compassion is the shaking of the heart of the good when there is another’s suffering. It is so called because it causes shaking , or because it is shaking .🔽It has the characteristic of occurring in the mode of removing another’s suffering. Its function is not to tolerate another’s suffering.

analyzed: avihiṃsā paccupaṭṭhānā dukkha abhibhūtānam anātha bhāva dassana padaṭṭhānā
translated: It is manifested as non-cruelty. Its proximate cause is seeing that those overwhelmed by suffering are helpless.

original: Modanti tāya, sayaṃ vā modatīti muditā. Sā pamodanalakkhaṇā, anissāyanarasā, arativighātapaccupaṭṭhānā,
analyzed: modanti tāya sayam vā modati iti muditā sā pamodana lakkhaṇā a nissāyana rasā a rati vighāta paccupaṭṭhānā
translated: It gladdens , or it gladdens oneself , thus it is gladness . Its characteristic is that of gladdening. Its function is to be non-dependent. It is manifested as the dispelling of dispassion .

original: sattānaṃ sampattidassanapadaṭṭhānā. Keci pana mettupekkhāyopi aniyate icchanti, taṃ
analyzed: sattānam sampatti dassana padaṭṭhānā keci pana mettupekkhāyaḥ api aniyate icchanti tam
translated: Its proximate cause is seeing the success of beings. But some want to include loving-kindness and equanimity among the things that are its proximate cause.🔽That should not be accepted,

original: na gahetabbaṃ. Atthato hi adoso eva mettā, tatramajjhattupekkhāyeva upekkhāti.
analyzed: na gahetabbam atthataḥ hi adosaḥ eva mettā tatram ajjhatta upekkhāya iva upekkhāti
translated: for in the case of loving-kindness it is only non-hate, and in the case of equanimity it is only non-delusion.

original: Kāyaduccaritato virati kāyaduccaritavirati. Eseva nayo sesesupi dvīsu. Lakkhaṇādito
analyzed: kāya duccaritataḥ virati kāya duccarita virati esa iva nayo sesesu pi dvīsu lakkhaṇa ādito
translated: Abstinence from bodily misconduct is the abstinence virtue consisting in bodily action. So too with the other two.

original: pana etā tissopi viratiyo kāyaduccaritādivatthūnaṃ avītikkamalakkhaṇā, kāyaduccaritādivatthuto🔽saṅkocanarasā, akiriyapaccupaṭṭhānā, saddhāhiriottappaappicchatādiguṇapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: pana etāḥ tissaḥ api viratiyaḥ kāya duccarita ādi vatthūnam avītikkama lakkhaṇā kāya duccarita ādi vatthuto  saṅkocana rasā akiriya paccupaṭṭhānā saddhā hiri uttappa appiccha tā ādi guṇa padaṭṭhānā
translated: As to characteristic, etc., all three abstinences have the characteristic of non- transgression of the bases consisting in bodily misconduct, etc.🔽Their function is to contract away from the bases consisting in bodily misconduct, and so on.🔽They are manifested as the avoidance of doing. Their proximate causes are such qualities as faith, conscience, shame, fewness of wishes, and so on.

original: Keci pana imāsu ekekaṃ niyataṃ viratiṃ icchanti. Evaṃ kāmāvacarapaṭhamamahākusalacittena
analyzed: keci pana imāsu ekekam niyatam viratim icchanti evam kāmāvacara paṭhama mahā kusala cittena
translated: But some want to make each abstinence a definite virtue.

original: ime tettiṃsa vā catuttiṃsa vā dhammā sampayogaṃ gacchantīti veditabbā.
analyzed: ime tettiṃsa vā catuttiṃsa vā dhammā sampayogam gacchanti iti veditabbā
translated: So it should be understood that with the first great basic jhāna consciousness of the sense sphere there are thirty-three or thirty-four states associated.

original: Yathā ca paṭhamena, evaṃ dutiyacittenāpi. Sasaṅkhārabhāvamattameva hi ettha viseso.
analyzed: yathā ca paṭhamena evam dutiya cittena api sa saṅkhāra bhāva mattam eva hi ettha visesaḥ
translated: And as with the first, so with the second, the only difference being the presence of applied thought.

original: Puna tatiyena ñāṇavippayogato ṭhapetvā amohaṃ avasesā dvattiṃsa vā tettiṃsa vā veditabbā.
analyzed: puna tatiyena ñāṇa vippayogato ṭhapetvā amoham avasesā dvattiṃsa vā tettiṃsa vā veditabbā
translated: Again, with the third, thirty-two or thirty-three should be understood, excluding non-delusion, which is dissociated from knowledge.

original: Tathā catutthenāpi sasaṅkhārabhāvamattameva viseso, paṭhame vuttesu pana ṭhapetvā
analyzed: tathā catutthena api sa saṅkhāra bhāva mattam eva visesaḥ paṭhame vuttesu pana ṭhapetvā
translated: And as with the third, so with the fourth, the only difference being the presence of applied thought. But excluding

original: pītiṃ avasesā pañcamena sampayogaṃ gacchanti. Somanassaṭṭhāne cettha upekkhāvedanā
analyzed: pītim avasesā pañcamena sampayogam gacchanti somanassa ṭṭhāne ca ittha upekkhā vedanā
translated: happiness, the remaining five occur in association with the fifth. Herein, the feeling is equanimity, which is in the place of joy.

analyzed: paviṭṭhā sā pana iṭṭha aniṭṭha viparīta anubhavana lakkhaṇā pakkhapāta upacchedana rasā
translated: Its characteristic is the experiencing of what is neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant. Its function is to abolish occurrence of pleasure and pain.

original: Yathā ca pañcamena, evaṃ chaṭṭhenāpi. Sasaṅkhāramattameva hoti viseso. Sattamena
analyzed: yathā ca pañcamena evam chaṭṭhena api sa saṅkhāra mattam eva hoti visesaḥ sattamena
translated: And as with the fifth, so with the sixth, the only difference being the presence of applied thought.

original: pana ṭhapetvā paññaṃ avasesā ekatiṃsa vā dvattiṃsa vā dhammā honti, tathā aṭṭhamenāpi.
analyzed: pana ṭhapetvā paññam avasesāḥ ekatiṃsa vā dvattiṃsa vā dhammāḥ honti tathā aṭṭhamena api
translated: But with the seventh, thirty-one or thirty-two should be understood, excluding understanding. And as with the seventh, so with the eighth,

original: Sasaṅkhāramattameva viseso. Evaṃ tāva kāmāvacarakusalacetasikā veditabbā.

analyzed: uddhata bhāvaḥ uddhaccam tam a vūpasama lakkhaṇam vāta abhighāta cala jalam viya an avaṭṭhāna rasam

original: Maññatīti māno. So uṇṇatilakkhaṇo, sampaggahaṇaraso, ketukamyatāpaccupaṭṭhāno, diṭṭhivippayuttalobhapadaṭṭhāno.🔽Issatīti issā. Sā parasampattīnaṃ usūyanalakkhaṇā, tattheva anabhiratirasā, tato vimukhabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, parasampattipadaṭṭhānā.

translated: Conceit is the conceiving of “I” and “mine.” Its characteristic is haughtiness; its function is to exalt oneself; its manifestation is the state of being a banner of vanity, like a flag; its proximate cause is craving for vanity.🔽Envy is envy of others’ success. Its characteristic is jealousy; its function is not to bear another’s success; it is manifested as annoyance, like the annoyance of a woman over a lover’s attentions to another woman; its proximate cause is another’s success.

original: Maccharabhāvo macchariyaṃ. Taṃ attano sampattīnaṃ niguhaṇalakkhaṇaṃ, tāsaṃyeva parehi sādhāraṇabhāvaakkhamanarasaṃ, saṅkocanapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, attasampattipadaṭṭhānaṃ.

translated: Avarice is avarice for one’s own chattels. Its characteristic is concealment; its function is not to bear sharing; its manifestation is niggardliness; its proximate cause is one’s own chattels.

original: Kucchitaṃ kataṃ kukataṃ, tassa bhāvo kukkuccaṃ. Taṃ pacchānutāpalakkhaṇaṃ, katākatānusocanarasaṃ, vippaṭisārapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, katākatapadaṭṭhānaṃ.
analyzed: kucchitam katam kukatam tassa bhāvaḥ kukkuccam tam pacchā anutāpa lakkhaṇam kata akata anusocana rasam vippaṭisāra paccupaṭṭhānam kata akata padaṭṭhānam
translated: The state of that is worry. Its characteristic is subsequent remorse. Its function is to regret what has been done and what has not been done. It is manifested as repentance. What has been done and what has not been done are its proximate cause.

original: Thinatā thinaṃ. Middhatā middhaṃ. Anussāhanasaṃsīdanatā, asattivighāto cāti attho.🔽Thinañca middhañca thinamiddhaṃ. Tattha thinaṃ anussāhanalakkhaṇaṃ, vīriyavinodanarasaṃ,
analyzed: thina tā thinam middha tā middham anussāhana saṃsīdana tā asatti vighātaḥ ca ati attho  thinam ca middham ca thinamiddham tattha thinam anussāhana lakkhaṇam vīriya vinodana rasam
translated: Dullness is dullness. Torpor is torpor. The meaning is: the state of being over- laid by sluggishness and the state of being overwhelmed by non-exertion.🔽Dullness and torpor are dullness-and-torpor. Herein, dullness has the characteristic of sluggishness. Its function is to obstruct arousing energy.

analyzed: saṃsīdana bhāva paccupaṭṭhānam middham akammañña tā lakkhaṇam onahana rasam līna tā paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: It is manifested as the state of sagging. Torpor has the characteristic of unserviceability. Its function is to overwhelm. It is manifested as sluggishness.

original: ubhayampi ayonisomanasikārapadaṭṭhānaṃ. Sesā kusale vuttanayena veditabbā.
analyzed: ubhayam pi a yonisoma nasikāra padaṭṭhānam sesā kusale vutta nayena veditabbā

analyzed: ca viseso tatiyena paṭhame vuttesu ṭhapetvā diṭṭhim sesāḥ aṭṭhārasa veditabbā māno  pana ittha aniyataḥ hoti diṭṭhiyā saha na uppajjati iti catutthena dutiye vuttesu ṭhapetvā

analyzed: diṭṭhim avasesāḥ veditabbāḥ ettha api ca mānaḥ aniyataḥ hoti pañcamena paṭhame vuttesu

Its proximate cause is the great primaries born of kamma that have desire to see as their intimation.🔽The ear has the characteristic of the intimation of the desire to hear.

original: Sotukāmatānidānakammasamuṭṭhānabhūtapasādalakkhaṇaṃ sotaṃ, saddesu āviñchanarasaṃ, sotaviññāṇassa ādhārabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ, sotukāmatānidānakammajabhūtapadaṭṭhānaṃ.

translated: The nose has the characteristic of being the sensitive matter originated by kamma that has as its condition the desire to smell. Its function is to react to smells. It is manifested as the support for nose-consciousness. Its proximate cause is the primary elements originated by kamma that have as their condition the desire to smell.🔽The tongue has the characteristic of being the sensitive matter originated by kamma that has as its condition the desire to taste. Its function is to react to tastes. It is manifested as the support for tongue-consciousness. Its proximate cause is the primary elements originated by kamma that have as their condition the desire to taste.

analyzed: phusitu kāma tā nidāna kamma samuṭṭhāna bhūta pasāda lakkhaṇo kāyo phoṭṭhabbesu āviñchana raso kāya viññāṇassa ādhāra bhāva paccupaṭṭhāno phusitu kāma tā nidāna kamma ja bhūta padaṭṭhāno
translated: The body has the characteristic of being the sensitive matter originated by kamma that has as its condition the desire to touch. Its function is to react to tangible data. It is manifested as the support for body-consciousness. Its proximate cause is the primary elements originated by kamma that have as their condition the desire to touch.

analyzed: yāyaḥ ojāya yāpenti yattha yattha ca pāṇino
translated: The nutriment that is called “physical nutriment”🔽Is that by which creatures live wherever they are.

analyzed: ayam tu kabaḷīkāro āhāro ti pavuccati

analyzed: anna pāna ādikam vatthu aggim harati kamma jam
translated: Carries on the work of fire, but cannot by itself

translated: Preserve the life faculty.🔽The nutriment that is called “contact”

analyzed: etāya bhāvaḥ viññāyati iti viññatti sayam vā kāya ggahaṇa anusārena viññāyati iti pi viññatti
translated: Or alternatively, it is intimation because it intimates by means of the body.

analyzed: kāyena kāya viññatti  tattha yā sahajātassa citta ja anila dhātuyā

analyzed: rūpassa calane hetu eka ākāra vikāra tā

analyzed: cāleti sahajam rūpam viññatti sahita āttanā
translated: It moves the conascent material instances together with the intimation.

analyzed: vacī viññatti niddese pana  paccayaḥ citta jātāya upādinnaka ghaṭṭane
translated: In the description of verbal intimation,

analyzed: ayam

analyzed: vacī viññatti viññeyyā saha sadda vasā pana

original: Rūpassa lahutādittayaniddese –🔽Heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva, rūpassa lahutādisu;🔽Tisso rūpavikārāti, viññātabbā vibhāvinā.

translated: Malleability of matter is the characteristic of plasticity; its function is to remove rigidity of matter; its manifestation is non-opposition to any kind of action; its footing is in malleable matter.

original: Sarīrakiriyānukūlakammaññatālakkhaṇā rūpassa kammaññatā, akammaññatāvinodanarasā, adubbalabhāvapaccupaṭṭhānā, kammaññatārūpapadaṭṭhānā. Etā pana tissopi na aññamaññaṃ vijahanti.

translated: Wieldiness of matter is the characteristic of wieldiness; its function is to remove unwieldiness; its manifestation is non-weakness; its footing is in wieldy matter. And these three are not found apart.

translated: In the description of growth and continuity:🔽Growth is said to be the increase

translated: But in characteristic, etc., growth is the growth of matter; its function is to make matter appear in the future; its manifestation is the state of being fully grown; its footing is in grown matter.

original: Pavattilakkhaṇā rūpassa santati, anuppabandhanarasā, anupacchedapaccupaṭṭhānā, anuppabandharūpapadaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: pavatti lakkhaṇā rūpassa santati an uppabandhana rasā an upaccheda paccupaṭṭhānā an uppabandha rūpa padaṭṭhānā

analyzed: pākaṭā rūpa dhammesu arūpesu apākaṭā

original: Rūpassa paripākatālakkhaṇā rūpassa jaratā, upanayanarasā, sabhāvānaṃ apagamepi nasabhāvāpagamapaccupaṭṭhānā vīhipurāṇabhāvo viya, paripaccamānarūpapadaṭṭhānā.

translated: The ageing of materiality has the characteristic of the maturing of materiality; its function is to bring about the state of having grown old; its manifestation is the non- disappearance of the individual essence even when there is disappearance of the particular states of materiality; its proximate cause is the materiality that is maturing, as in the case of the state of having grown old in the village of Vēhali.

original: Paribhedalakkhaṇā rūpassa aniccatā, saṃsīdanarasā, khayavayapaccupaṭṭhānā, paribhijjamānarūpapadaṭṭhānāti veditabbāti.

translated: Impermanence has the characteristic of dissolution of materiality; its function is to cause materiality to decay; its manifestation is the state of having been destroyed; its proximate cause is the materiality that is dissolving, as in the case of the state of having been destroyed in the village of Vēhali.

analyzed: evam catuvīsati upādā rūpāni veditabbāni

analyzed: addhā muni isi sambuddhaḥ na atthi nīvaraṇā tava ati ca thinam iddha nīvaraṇam avijjā nīvaraṇam ca  nīvaraṇa sampayuttanti sampayutta vacanato ca mahā apakaraṇa paṭṭhāne nīvaraṇam dhammam
translated: For you have no hindrance at all” ,🔽and “The hindrance of torpor and the hindrance of ignorance are associated with the hindrances” , and in the “Great Guide” : “With a hindrance as condition there arises a hindrance, not a pre-arisen condition” .

analyzed: paṭicca nīvaraṇaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati na purejāta paccayā ati arūpe pi kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam

analyzed: ca arūpam eva middhanti paṭikkhipitabbā
translated: So it should be denied that drowsiness is formless.

analyzed: arūpe pi pana itassa middhassa uppatti pāṭhataḥ

Āpodhātuyā sambhavarūpaṃ, upacayasantatīti jātirūpaṃ, jaratāaniccatādīhi
analyzed: niṭṭham ettha avagantabbāḥ arūpanti ca viññunā  apare bala rūpena saddhim ekūnatiṃsa sambhava rūpena saddhim tiṃsa jāti rūpena saddhim  ekatiṃsa roga rūpena saddhim dvattiṃsa rūpāni iti vadanti te pi visum visum  abhāvam dassetvā paṭikkhipitabbā vāyodhātuyā gahitāya bala rūpam gahitam eva aññam  bala rūpam nāma natthi āpodhātuyā sambhava rūpam upacaya santati iti jāti rūpam jara tā anicca tā ādīhi
translated: The wise should understand that it is formless, according to the texts.

original: rogarūpaṃ gahitaṃ, aññaṃ rogarūpaṃ nāma natthīti, tasmā aṭṭhavīsatividhāneva rūpānīti.
analyzed: roga rūpam gahitam aññam roga rūpam nāma natthi iti tasmai aṭṭhavīsati vidhānā iva rūpāni iti
translated: Others say that there are twenty-nine kinds of materiality together with the materiality of the faculties, thirty kinds together with the materiality of origination, thirty-one kinds together with the materiality of birth, and thirty-two kinds together with the materiality of disease. When the air element is included, the materiality of the faculties is included too, for there is no other materiality of the faculties. When the water element is included, the materiality of origination, the materiality of growth, and the materiality of continuity are included. When the materiality of birth is included, the materiality of ageing, the materiality of impermanence, and so on, are included. There is no other materiality of disease. So there are only twenty-eight kinds of materiality.

translated: and it is of three kinds as visible-data base, etc., that is to say, visible data as the visible-data base are visible and impingeable; the eleven kinds of derivative material, namely, the four beginning with colour , the four beginning with sex , and the seven beginning with sound , are invisible but impingeable; the remaining sixteen kinds of derivative material, namely, the four beginning with bodily intimation , the four beginning with the temperature-originated kinds of matter , the four beginning with nutriment-originated matter , and the four beginning with space-element-originated matter , are invisible and impingeable. That which is born of kamma is kamma-born; the eight faculties and the physical heart- basis are kamma-born; that which is born with other conditions than kamma is not kamma-born; that which is born neither from kamma nor with other conditions than kamma is neither kamma-born nor not kamma-born; that is, ageing and the impermanence of material instances. So it is of three kinds.

translated: and it is of three kinds as visible-data base, etc., that is to say, the visible-data base is visible and impingeable; the eleven kinds of materiality consisting of the ten sensitive-data and the sound-data are invisible and impingeable; the remaining sixteen kinds of materiality consisting of the subtle materiality are invisible and impingeable. It is of three kinds as born of kamma, etc., that is to say, the eight faculties and the physical heart- basis are born of kamma; the rest are not born of kamma; and ageing and dissolution are neither born of kamma nor not born of kamma. It is of three kinds as seen, heard, sensed, and cognized, etc., that is to say, the visible-data base is seen; the sound-data base is heard; the mind-consciousness element and the mental data base are sensed; the rest are cognized; and ageing and dissolution are neither seen nor heard nor sensed nor cognized. It is of three kinds as door and as physical basis, etc., that is to say, the eye-sensitivity, etc., are a door and a physical basis; the physical heart-basis is a physical basis only and not a door; the rest are neither a door nor a physical basis. It is of three kinds as door and as faculty, etc., that is to say, the eye-sensitivity, etc., are a door and a faculty; the ear-sensitivity, etc., are a door only and not a faculty; the physical-basis sensitivity is a faculty only and not a door; the rest are neither a door nor a faculty. It is of three kinds as physical basis and as faculty, etc., that is to say, the physical-basis sensitivity is a physical basis and a faculty; the eye-sensitivity, etc., are a faculty only and not a physical basis; the rest are neither a physical basis nor a faculty.
