analyzed: paññapetabbataḥ paññatti iti vuttā ahanti hi rūpa ādayaḥ dhamme upādāya paṭicca kāraṇam  katvā yathā te rūpa ādayaḥ dhammāḥ uppāda vayavantaḥ na evaṃvidhā kevalam loka saṅketena
translated: As “I” and “mine,” “other” and “another’s,” “couch” and “chair,” and so on. So firstly it is called a description because it can be given a name. For the “I” is given a name and spoken of by the mere conventional term “I” in dependence on and contingent upon the states beginning with material form, making them its reason,

original: siddhā yā ayaṃ “aha”nti kathīyati ceva paññāpīyati ca, esā paññattīti attho.
analyzed: siddhā yā ayam ahanti kathīyati ca iva paññāpīyati ca esā paññattī iti
translated: just as those states beginning with material form are spoken of and given a name by the mere conventional term “I” in dependence on and contingent upon the “I,” making it their reason. But the states beginning with material form are not of the same essence as the “I,” since they are originated and perishable. So the meaning is that this “I” is spoken of and given a name by the mere conventional term “I” established by social agreement.

original: Idāni paññāpanato paññattiṃ pakāsetuṃ “nāmaṃ nāmakamma”ntiādimāha. Tattha nāmanti
analyzed: idāni paññāpanataḥ paññattim pakāsetum nāmam nāma kamman ti ādim āha tattha nāmam ti
translated: Now, in order to demonstrate the description by means of the description itself, he said “name-making, etc.,” as “name” and “description.” Herein,

original: taṃ taṃ dhammaṃ “esa itthannāmo nāmā”ti paññapeti, tasmā taṃ paññattīti pavuccati.
analyzed: tam tam dhammaṃ esaḥ itthannāmaḥ nāma ati paññapeti tasmā tam paññattī iti pavuccati
translated: He describes that and that idea as “This is called so and so,” thus it is called description.

original: Nāmakammantiādīni tassā eva vevacanāni. Ayaṃ paññāpanato paññatti nāma.
analyzed: nāma kamma anti ādīni tassāḥ eva vevacanāni ayam paññāpanataḥ paññatti nāma
translated: The terms “naming,” etc., are synonyms for that. This is description as description.

original: Sā panesā tajjāpaññatti upādāpaññatti upanidhāpaññattīti tividhā hoti. Tattha tajjāpaññatti
analyzed: sā pana isā tajjā paññatti upādā paññatti upanidhā paññatti iti tividhā hoti tattha
translated: But this description as description is threefold as description of what is, description of what is taken up, and description of what is placed beside. Herein,

original: nāma cakkhusotarūpasaddapathavītejovāyotiādinayappavattā. Upādāpaññatti pana samūhāsamūhavasena🔽duvidhā hoti. Tattha samūhapaññatti nāma rūpārūpadhammesu ekassa vā bahūnaṃ vā nāmaṃ
analyzed: nāma cakkhu sota rūpa sadda pathavī tejaḥ vāyu ti ādi naya ppavattā upādā paññatti pana samūha asamūha vasena  duvidhā hoti tattha samūha paññatti nāma rūpa arūpa dhammesu ekassa vā bahūnam vā nāmaṃ
translated: description of what is is that which occurs thus: “Eye, ear, visible data, sounds, earth, water, fire,” and so on. Description of what is taken up, however,🔽is twofold as description of a collection and description of what is not a collection.

original: gahetvā samūhamevopādāya vuccati. Kathaṃ? Acchataracchaghaṭapaṭādippabhedā. Ayaṃ
analyzed: gahetvā samūham evā upādāya vuccati katham accha taraccha ghaṭa paṭa ādi ppabhedāḥ ayam
translated: Herein, description of a collection is that which is said of a collection only by taking a name for one or many material or immaterial ideas. How? “Cloth, blanket, sheet, hide,” and so on.

analyzed: samūha paññatti nāma a samūha paññatti pana disā kāsa kāla nimitta abhāva nirodha ādi bhedā
translated: This is called description of a collection. Description of what is not a collection is that which is said of what is not a collection, such as directions, space, time, signs, non-existence, cessation, and so on.

original: Yadā pana sā vijjamānaṃ paramatthaṃ jotayati, tadā “vijjamānapaññattī”ti pavuccati.
analyzed: yadā pana sā vijjamānam param attham jotayati tadā vijjamānapaññattī iti pavuccati
translated: But when it illuminates what exists, then it is called “description of what exists.”

original: Yadā avijjamānaṃ samūhāsamūhabhedaṃ nāmamattaṃ jotayati, tadā “avijjamānapaññattī”ti🔽pavuccati. Duvidhāpi panesā sotadvārajavanānantaraṃ gahitapubbasaṅketamanodvārajavanaviññāṇena
analyzed: yadā avijjamānam samūha a samūha bhedam nāma mattam jotayati tadā avijjamāna paññatti iti  pavuccati duvidhā api pana esā sota dvāra javana anantaram gahita pubba saṅketa manaḥ dvāra javana viññāṇena
translated: When it indicates a mere name, which is not actually there, as a class or as a class-genus, then it is called “a designation not actually there.”🔽But in both cases it is cognized by the mind-door impulsion consciousness that has had the previous designation imputed to it.

original: viññāyati. Yāya gahitapubbasaṅketena manodvārajavanaviññāṇena paññāpīyati. Yaṃ sandhāya🔽“vijjamānapaññatti, avijjamānapaññatti, vijjamānena avijjamānapaññatti, avijjamānena
analyzed: viññāyati yāya gahita pubba saṅketena manaḥ dvāra javana viññāṇena paññāpīyati yam sandhāya  vijjamāna paññatti avijjamāna paññatti vijjamānena avijjamāna paññatti avijjamānena
translated: And it is designated by the mind-door impulsion consciousness that has had the previous designation imputed to it.

analyzed: vijjamāna paññatti vijjamānena vijjamāna paññatti avijjamānena avijjamāna paññatti iti
translated: With reference to this it is said: “Designation actually there, designation not actually there, designation actually there as not actually there, designation not actually there as actually there, designation actually there as actually there, designation not actually there as not actually there” .

original: chakkanayo vutto. Tattha paramatthato vijjamānānaṃ rūpādīnaṃ paññāpanā vijjamānapaññatti.
analyzed: chakka nayaḥ vuttaḥ tattha paramatthataḥ vijjamānānam rūpa ādīnam paññāpanā vijjamāna paññatti
translated: This is the sixfold method. Herein, the designation of visible data, etc., which are actually there in the ultimate sense, is “designation actually there.”

original: Tathā avijjamānānamitthipurisādīnaṃ paññāpanā avijjamānapaññatti. Ṭhapetvā pana vacanatthaṃ
analyzed: tathā a vijjamānānam mitthi purisa ādīnam paññāpanā avijjamāna paññatti ṭhapetvā pana vacana attham
translated: And the designation of women, men, etc., which are not actually there in the ultimate sense, is “designation not actually there.”🔽But apart from the meaning of the words

original: kenaci ākārena anupalabbhamānānaṃ pañcamasaccādīnaṃ, titthiyaparikappitānaṃ vā pakatipurisādīnaṃ
analyzed: kenaci ākārena anupalabbhamānānam pañcama sacca ādīnam titthiya parikappitānam vā pakati purisa ādīnam
translated: and of the fifth truth, etc., which are not found in any way, or of the individual essence, etc., imagined by sectarians,

analyzed: paññāpanā api a vijjamāna paññattiyā iva tevijjaḥ chaḍabhiñño ti evamādi naya ppavattā
translated: the description is description of what is non-existent. The description that occurs in the way beginning, “He is one of triple knowledge, of six kinds of direct- knowledge”

analyzed: vijjamānena avijjamāna paññatti itthi saddo purisa saddo ti evamādikā avijjamānena

translated: is description of what is non-existent by what is existent. The description that occurs in the way beginning, “Eye-consciousness, ear-consciousness”🔽is description of what is existent by what is existent. The description that occurs in the way beginning, “A prince, a brahman youth, a bhikkhu youth”

analyzed: khattiya kumāraḥ brāhmaṇa kumāraḥ bhikkhu kumāraḥ ti evamādikā avijjamānena avijjamāna paññatti iti
translated: is description of what is non-existent by what is non-existent.

original: evaṃ vuttā cha paññattiyopi ettheva saṅgahaṃ gacchanti. Ayaṃ upādāpaññatti nāma.
analyzed: evam vuttā cha paññattiyaḥ pi ettha iva saṅgaham gacchanti ayam upādāpaññatti nāma
translated: So the six kinds of description mentioned in the way just stated are included here. This is called description by assuming.

original: Upanidhāpaññattipi etissā eva pabhedā, sā pana “dīghaṃ upanidhāya rasso, rassaṃ upanidhāya
analyzed: upanidhā paññattipi etissāḥ eva pabhedā sā pana dīgham upanidhāya rassaḥ rassam upanidhāya
translated: Description by postulating is also a kind of description by assuming. It is described thus: “The long in contrast with the short, the short in contrast with the long,

original: dīgho”tiādinayappavattā “kapaṇaṃ mānusakaṃ rajjaṃ dibbasukhaṃ upanidhāyā”ti evamādikā
analyzed: dīghaḥ ti ādi naya ppavattā kapaṇam mānusakam rajjam dibba sukham upanidhāya ati evamādikā
translated: “Long” and so on, and the statement “Human sovereignty is paltry when set beside divine bliss,” and so on.

original: ca, tasmā paññapetabbato ca paññāpanato ca paññattīti veditabbā. Samaññā samattā.
analyzed: ca tasmā paññapetabbataḥ ca paññāpanataḥ ca paññatti iti veditabbā samaññā samattā
translated: So it should be understood as “what is laid down” because it is laid down and because it is what is laid down. The explanation of the term is ended.🔽In the ultimate sense, what is laid down

original: Paramatthato ca paññatti, tatiyā koṭi na vijjati;
analyzed: paramatthato ca paññatti tatiyā koṭi na vijjati
translated: Has no third position.🔽Skilled in two positions, he does not waver

original: Dvīsu ṭhānesu kusalo, paravādesu na kampati.
analyzed: dvīsu ṭhānesu kusalaḥ paravādesu na kampati
translated: In the doctrines of others.🔽So in the Abhidhamma-avatāra called

analyzed: ettha āha niddiṭṭhā kusala ādayaḥ nāma dhammā na pana etesam kārakaḥ attā niddiṭṭhaḥ tassa  hi kārakassa vedakassa attanaḥ abhāve kusala akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ abhāvaḥ siyā tesam abhāve
translated: Here it may be said: “The profitable, etc., states have been demonstrated, but the self that is their maker has not been demonstrated.🔽For if there were no such self as a doer, a feeler, then the profitable and unprofitable would not exist;

original: tadāyattavuttīnaṃ tesaṃ vipākānamabhāvo hoti, tasmā kusalādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ desanā
analyzed: tad āyatta vuttīnam tesam vipākānam abhāvaḥ hoti tasmā kusala ādīnam dhammānam desanā
translated: and if they did not exist, then their results, which are dependent on them for their occurrence, would not exist either. So the teaching of the profitable, etc.,

original: niratthikāti? Atra vuccate – nāyaṃ niratthikā, sātthikāvāyaṃ desanā. Yadi kārakassābhāvā
analyzed: niratthikā ati atra vuccate  na ayam niratthikā sātthikā ava ayam desanā yadi
translated: “But is it not useless?” —Here it may be said as follows: This is not useless; it is a teaching that has a purpose. If, because of the non-existence of a doer,

original: kusalādīnamabhāvo siyā, tassa parikappitassa attanopi abhāvo siyā. Kiṃ kāraṇanti
analyzed: kusala ādīnam abhāvaḥ siyā tassa parikappitassa attanaḥ api abhāvaḥ siyā kim kāraṇam ti
translated: the non-existence of the wholesome, etc., were to come about, then the non-existence of the self that is imagined would also come about. Why?

original: ce? Tassa attano aññassa kārakassābhāvato. Kārakābhāvepi kattā attā atthīti ce? Tathā
analyzed: ce tassa attanaḥ aññassa kārakassa abhāvataḥ kāraka abhāve pi kattā attā atthi iti ce tathā
translated: Because, in the absence of that self, there is no other doer. But if you say that the self exists as the doer even in the absence of a doer,

original: kusalādīnampi asatipi kattari atthitā upagantabbā, kutoyaṃ tava tatthānurodho, idha🔽virodhoti. Athāpi yathā pana loke kārakābhāvepi pathavīāpatejautuādayo paṭicca aṅkurādīnaṃ
analyzed: kusala ādīnam pi asati pi kattari atthi tā upagantabbā kutas yam tava tattha anurodhaḥ idha  virodhaḥ iti atha api yathā pana loke kāraka abhāve pi paṭicca aṅkura ādīnam
translated: then you must admit that the wholesome, etc., exist even in the absence of a doer. Why do you insist on that and reject this?

original: abhinibbatti dissati, tathā etesampi kusalādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ hetupaccayasāmaggiyā abhinibbatti hotīti veditabbā.
analyzed: abhinibbatti dissati tathā etesam pi kusala ādīnam dhammānam hetu paccaya sāmaggiyā abhinibbatti hoti iti veditabbā
translated: But if you say that just as in the world the production of sprouts, etc., is seen to occur in dependence on earth, water, fire, air, etc., even in the absence of a doer, so too the production of the wholesome, etc., comes about through the combination of causes and conditions,

original: Athāpi cettha tassā paññāya parikappito nicco dhuvo kusalādīnaṃ kattā attā paramatthato
analyzed: atha api ca ittha tassā paññāya parikappitaḥ niccaḥ dhuvaḥ kusala ādīnam kattā attā paramatthato
translated: then it must be said that the self that is imagined by you as the permanent, eternal doer of the wholesome, etc., does not exist in the ultimate sense.

original: atthīti ce? Tamupaparikkhissāma tāva, so pana tāva attā kārako vedako kiṃ sacetano🔽vā, udāhu acetano vāti? Kiñcettha – yadi acetano siyā, pākāratarupāsāṇasadiso siyā.

translated: If there is, we shall examine it. But is this self that does the act and feels the result conscious or unconscious? What is said here? If it is unconscious, it will be like a clod of earth, a piece of wood, a pebble.

original: Tassa kārakavedakattābhāvo siyā. Yadi sacetano, so cetanāya añño vā siyā, anañño
analyzed: tassa kāraka vedaka ttā abhāvaḥ siyā yadi sa cetano so cetanāya aññaḥ vā siyā anaññaḥ
translated: It will be devoid of the capacity to do and feel. If it is conscious, is it the same as consciousness or not?

original: vā. Athānañño, cetanāya nāse attanopi nāso siyā. Kiṃ kāraṇanti ce? Cetanāya anaññattā.
analyzed: vā atha anaññaḥ cetanāya nāse attano pi nāso siyā kim kāraṇam ti ce cetanāya anañña ttā
translated: If it is not the same, then with the cessation of consciousness there would be the cessation of the self, because of their dissimilarity. Why? Because of the non-identity of the self and consciousness.

original: Athāpi bhavato adhippāyo evaṃ siyā, attano pana nāso na bhavati niccattā, cetanāyayeva
analyzed: atha api bhavataḥ adhippāyaḥ evam siyā attanaḥ pana nāsaḥ na bhavati niccattā
translated: If, however, your view is that the self does not cease because of its permanence, but consciousness ceases,

analyzed: nāsaḥ bhavati iti vuccate attanaḥ a nāse sati nāsaḥ na bhavati kim kāraṇam ti  ce cetanāya an aññattā cetanattānam an aññatte sati
translated: we reply that if the self does not cease, consciousness does not cease either. Why?🔽Because of the non-identity of the self and consciousness. If the self and consciousness were not identical, then consciousness would cease, but not the self.

original: attanoti ayuttametaṃ. Atha cetanāyayeva vināse visesakāraṇaṃ natthi, attāva nassatu,
analyzed: attanoti ayuttam etam atha vināse visesa kāraṇam natthi attā ava nassatu
translated: This is impossible. If there is no special reason for the destruction of consciousness, then let the self be destroyed.

analyzed: tiṭṭhatu cetanā atha cetanāya nāse attanaḥ nāsaḥ na bhavati iti ce cetanāya attā aññaḥ  siyā atha aññassa attassa nāse sati sayam nāsaḥ na bhavati evañca sati cetanāya  an aññaḥ attā iti tava paṭiññā hīnā atha api cetanattānam an aññatte sati attanaḥ

original: Tattha kiṃ tvaṃ cetanattānaṃ lakkhaṇakatamaññattaṃ vadesi, udāhu desantarakatamaññattanti?
analyzed: tattha kim tvam cetanattānam lakkhaṇa kata maññattam vadesi udāhu desantara kata maññattam ti
translated: Herein, do you say that the difference is in the characteristic of the self or in the self’s being in different places?

translated: If so, then why is there no destruction of the self, as there is of the consciousness, because of the non-separation of the self from the parts of the body, as there is of consciousness?🔽If there is no reason for the destruction of consciousness and not of the self, then, according to your theory, the self alone should be destroyed and not the consciousness.🔽If the self is not destroyed when the consciousness is destroyed, then the two are not non-separate. If that is so, what is the fault?🔽But you said that just as the self is different from the parts of the body, such as the form, feeling, etc., so also the consciousness is different from the parts of the consciousness.🔽This is a low opinion, because it is a theory of non-separation.🔽If, like the form, feeling, etc., the self is not destroyed when the parts of the self are destroyed, then, like the consciousness, the self is not destroyed when the consciousness is destroyed.

original: asi. Atha vuttappakārato viparītaṃ vā siyā, tava attā nassatu, cetanā tiṭṭhatu. Athevaṃ
analyzed: asi atha vutta ppakārataḥ viparītam vā siyā tava attā nassatu cetanā tiṭṭhatu atha evam
translated: and the self is not destroyed? If so, then why is it that the self is not destroyed when the consciousness is destroyed? If you say that there is no reason, then according to your theory the self itself should be destroyed, and the consciousness should remain. If you say that when the consciousness is destroyed the self is not destroyed, then the two are not the same. If that is so, what is the fault? But you said that just as the characteristics of visible form, odour, etc., are different from each other even though they occur in the same place, so too the characteristics of the self and consciousness are different from each other even though they occur in the same place. Your assertion is inferior. If, like visible form, odour, etc., the self does not perish even though the consciousness perishes, then you are at fault. If it is the opposite of what you have said, then let the self perish and let the consciousness remain.

analyzed: imesu pana catūsu magga ñāṇesu ye dhammā yena ñāṇena pahātabbā tesam pahānam evam  veditabbam etāni hi yathāyogam
translated: Now, as to the states that are to be abandoned by means of these four kinds of knowledge of the path, their abandoning should be understood in this way.

analyzed: ogha yoga nīvaraṇa parāmāsa upādāna anusaya mala akusala kammapatha akusala cittuppāda saṅkhātānam pahāna karāni
translated: For these kinds of knowledge are the abandoners of fetters, defilements, perversions, mundane states, miserliness, perversions of view, knots, bad ways, taints, floods, bonds, hindrances, adherences, clingings, inherent tendencies, stains, unprofitable courses of action, and unprofitable thoughts.

original: Tattha saṃyojanānīti dasa saṃyojanāni. Seyyathidaṃ – rūparāgārūparāgamānauddhaccāvijjāti
analyzed: tattha saṃyojanāni iti dasa saṃyojanāni sā iyyathidam
translated: Herein, as to the fetters : there are ten fetters, that is to say, greed for sense desires, resentment, pride, ignorance, views, uncertainty, conceit , greed for fine- material existence, greed for immaterial existence, and conceit.

original: ime pañca uddhaṃbhāgiyasaṃyojanāni nāma. Sakkāyadiṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbataparāmāso
analyzed: ime pañca uddhaṃbhāgiya saṃyojanāni nāma sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāso
translated: These first five are called higher fetters. Personality view, uncertainty, and misapprehension of virtue and duty,

original: kāmarāgo paṭighoti ime pañca adhobhāgiyasaṃyojanāni nāma.
analyzed: kāmarāgaḥ paṭighaḥ ti ime pañca adhobhāgiya saṃyojanāni nāma
translated: greed for sense desires, and resentment are called lower fetters.

original: Kilesāti dasa kilesā. Seyyathidaṃ – lobho doso moho māno diṭṭhi vicikicchā thinaṃ uddhaccaṃ ahirikaṃ anottappanti.
analyzed: kilesā ati dasa kilesā sā iyyathidam lobhaḥ dosaḥ mohaḥ mānaḥ diṭṭhi vicikicchā thinam uddhaccam ahirikam anottappanti
translated: As to the defilements : there are ten defilements, that is to say, greed, hate, delusion, conceit, false view, uncertainty, rigidity, agitation, consciencelessness, and shamelessness.

original: Micchattāti dasa micchattā. Seyyathidaṃ – micchādiṭṭhi micchāsaṅkappo micchāvācā micchākammanto micchāājīvo micchāvāyāmo micchāsati micchāsamādhi micchāñāṇaṃ micchāvimuttīti.
analyzed: micchattā ati dasa micchattā sā iyyathidam micchā diṭṭhi micchā saṅkappaḥ micchā vācā micchā kammantaḥ micchā ājīvaḥ micchā vāyāmaḥ micchā sati micchā samādhi micchā ñāṇam micchā vimutti iti
translated: Wrongnesses: there are ten wrongnesses, that is to say, wrong view, wrong resolve, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong concentration, wrong knowledge, and wrong deliverance.

original: Lokadhammāti aṭṭha lokadhammā lābho alābho yaso ayaso nindā pasaṃsā sukhaṃ dukkhanti.🔽Idha pana kāraṇūpacārena lābhādivatthukassa anunayassa, alābhādivatthukassa paṭighassa
analyzed: loka dhammā ati aṭṭha loka dhammā lābhaḥ alābhaḥ yasaḥ ayasaḥ nindā pasaṃsā sukham dukkham  idha pana kāraṇa upacārena lābha ādi vatthukassa anunayassa alābha ādi vatthukassa paṭighassa
translated: Worldly ideas: there are eight worldly ideas, that is to say, gain and non-gain, fame and non-fame, blame and praise, pleasure and pain.

original: cetaṃ lokadhammagahaṇena gahaṇaṃ katanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Macchariyānīti pañca macchariyāni āvāsamacchariyaṃ kulamacchariyaṃ lābhamacchariyaṃ🔽dhammamacchariyaṃ vaṇṇamacchariyanti. Imāni āvāsādīsu aññesaṃ sādhāraṇabhāvaṃ asahanākārena
analyzed: ca itam loka dhamma gahaṇena gahaṇam katan ti veditabbam  mad śariyāni iti pañca mad śariyāni āvāsa mad śariyam kula mad śariyam lābha mad śariyam  dhamma macchariyam vaṇṇa macchariyanti imāni āvāsa ādīsu aññesam sādhāraṇa bhāvam a sahanā ākārena
translated: But here the inclusion of the eight worldly ideas should be understood as the inclusion of the underlying tendency to lust that has gain, etc., as its object, and of the underlying tendency to aversion that has non-gain, etc., as its object, by naming their associated earth element.

analyzed: pavattāni macchariyāni
translated: Miserliness: there are five kinds of miserliness, that is to say, miserliness about dwellings, miserliness about families, miserliness about gains, miserliness about virtue, and miserliness about views. These are miserlinesses that occur in the form of an unwillingness to share dwellings, etc., with others.

original: Vipallāsāti aniccadukkhaanattaasubhesuyeva vatthūsu “niccaṃ sukhaṃ attā subha”nti evaṃ pavattā saññāvipallāso cittavipallāso diṭṭhivipallāsoti ime tayo vipallāsā.
analyzed: vipallāsā ti anicca dukkha anatta asubhesu yeva vatthūsu niccam sukham attā subhan ti evam pavattā saññā vipallāso citta vipallāso diṭṭhi vipallāso ti ime tayaḥ vipallāsā
translated: “Perversions” are the three perversions, namely, the perversion of perception, the perversion of cognizance, and the perversion of view, which occur only in regard to impermanence, pain, not-self, and foulness, respectively, as permanence, pleasure, self, and beauty.

original: Ganthāti cattāro ganthā abhijjhākāyagantho, byāpādo, sīlabbataparāmāso, idaṃsaccābhiniveso kāyaganthoti.
analyzed: ganthā ati cattāro ganthāḥ abhijjhā kāya ganthaḥ byāpādaḥ sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ kāya gantho ti
translated: “Fetters” are the four fetters, namely, greed as a fetter, ill will as a fetter, esteeming of virtue and duty as a fetter, and assertion of a view as a fetter.

analyzed: agati iti chanda dosa moha bhayāni āsavā ti cattāro āsavā kāma rāga bhava rāgam icchā diṭṭhi avijja āsavo ti
translated: “Tendencies” are the four tendencies, namely, the tendencies to lust, to aversion, to conceit, and to ignorance.

original: Oghayogānītipi tesamevādhivacanaṃ. Nīvaraṇānīti kāmacchandādayo. Parāmāsoti micchādiṭṭhiyā adhivacanaṃ.
analyzed: ogha yogāni iti pi tesam eva adhivacanam nīvaraṇāni iti micchādiṭṭhiyāḥ adhivacanam
translated: “Floods” and “bonds” are also terms for these same four. “Hindrances” are the hindrances of lust, etc. “Assurances” is a term for wrong view.🔽“Clingings” are the four kinds of clinging, namely, clinging to sensual pleasures, clinging to views, clinging to virtue and duty, and clinging to a doctrine of self.

original: Upādānāti cattāri upādānāni kāmupādānādīnīti. Anusayāti satta anusayā kāmarāgānusayo paṭighamānadiṭṭhivicikicchābhavarāgāvijjānusayoti. Malāti tayo malā – lobho doso mohoti.
analyzed: upādānā ati cattāri upādānāni kāma upādāna ādīni iti anusayāti satta anusayā kāma rāga anusayo malā ati tayaḥ malā lobhaḥ dosaḥ moho ti
translated: “Underlying tendencies” are the seven underlying tendencies, namely, the underlying tendencies to lust, to aversion, to conceit, to false view, to uncertainty, to passion, and to resistance. “Defilements” are the three defilements, namely, greed, hate, and delusion.

original: Akusalakammapathāti dasa akusalakammapathā. Seyyathidaṃ – pāṇātipāto adinnādānaṃ
analyzed: akusala kamma pathā ati dasa akusala kamma pathā sā iyyathidam pāṇa atipātaḥ adinnādānam
translated: The ten courses of unwholesome kamma are called the unwholesome courses of kamma. They are: killing living beings, taking what is not given,

original: kāmesumicchācāro musāvādo pisuṇavācā pharusavācā samphappalāpo abhijjhā byāpādo micchādiṭṭhīti dasa.
analyzed: kāmesu micchā ācāraḥ musāvādaḥ pisuṇa vācā pharusa vācā samphappalāpaḥ abhijjhā byāpādaḥ micchādiṭṭhi iti dasa
translated: The ten unprofitable courses of action are these: killing breathing things, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, false speech, malicious speech, harsh speech, gossip, covetousness, ill will, wrong view.

original: Akusalacittuppādāti lobhamūlāni aṭṭha, dosamūlāni dve, mohamūlāni dveti ime dvādasāti.
analyzed: akusala cittuppādā ti lobha mūlāni aṭṭha dosa mūlāni dve moha mūlāni dve iti ime dvādasā ati
translated: The twelve unprofitable thought-arisings are these: the eight rooted in greed, the two rooted in hate, and the two rooted in delusion.

original: Etesaṃ saṃyojanādīnaṃ etāni yathāsambhavaṃ pahānakarāni. Kathaṃ? Saṃyojanesu tāva
analyzed: saṃyojana ādīnam etāni yathāsambhavam pahāna karāni katham saṃyojanesu
translated: These are the abandoners of these fetters, etc., according to the appropriate occasion. How? As regards the fetters:

analyzed: sakkāya diṭṭhi vicikicchā sīlabbata parāmāsāḥ apāya gamanīyā kāma rāga paṭighā ati ete paṭhama magga ñāṇa vajjhāḥ
translated: personality view, uncertainty, misapprehension of virtue and duty, and the lust for sensual desires and for existence that lead to the states of loss, are abandoned by the first path knowledge;

original: sesā kāmarāgapaṭighā oḷārikā dutiyamaggañāṇavajjhā, sukhumā tatiyamaggañāṇavajjhā,
analyzed: sesā kāma rāga paṭighā oḷārikā dutiya magga ñāṇa vajjhā sukhumā tatiya magga ñāṇa vajjhā
translated: the gross lust for sensual desires and hate are abandoned by the second path knowledge, the subtle lust for sensual desires and hate are abandoned by the third path knowledge;

analyzed: rūpa rāga ādayaḥ catuttha magga ñāṇa vajjhāḥ eva
translated: and the lust for fine-material existence, lust for immaterial existence, conceit, restlessness, and ignorance are abandoned by the fourth path knowledge.

original: Kilesesu diṭṭhivicikicchā paṭhamamaggañāṇavajjhā, doso tatiyamaggañāṇavajjho, lobhamohamānathinauddhaccaahirikānottappāni catutthamaggañāṇavajjhāni.
analyzed: kilesesu diṭṭhi vicikicchā paṭhama magga ñāṇa vajjhā doso tatiya magga ñāṇa vajjhaḥ lobha moha māna thina auddhacca ahirika anottappāni catuttha magga ñāṇa vajjhāni
translated: In the case of the defilements, wrong view and uncertainty are abandoned by the first path knowledge; hate is abandoned by the third path knowledge; and greed, delusion, conceit, agitation, lack of conscience, and lack of shame are abandoned by the fourth path knowledge.

original: Micchattesu micchādiṭṭhi musāvādo micchākammanto micchāājīvoti ime paṭhamamaggañāṇavajjhā,
analyzed: micchattesu micchādiṭṭhi musāvādaḥ micchākammantaḥ micchāājīvaḥ ti ime paṭhama magga ñāṇa vajjhāḥ
translated: In the case of the wrongnesses, wrong view, false speech, wrong action, and wrong livelihood are abandoned by the first path knowledge;

original: micchāsaṅkappo pisuṇavācā pharusavācāti ime tatiyamaggañāṇavajjhā, cetanāyeva cettha
analyzed: micchā saṅkappaḥ pisuṇa vācā pharusa vācā ati ime tatiya magga ñāṇa vajjhā cetanāya iva ca ittha
translated: wrong thinking, malicious speech, and harsh speech are abandoned by the third path knowledge. Here the volition itself should be understood as wrong speech.

analyzed: micchā vācā ati veditabbā samphappalāpa micchā vāyāma sati samādhi vimutti ñāṇāni catuttha magga ñāṇa vajjhāni
translated: Wrong concentration, wrong mindfulness, wrong effort, wrong deliverance, and wrong knowledge are abandoned by the fourth path knowledge.

original: Lokadhammesu paṭigho tatiyamaggañāṇavajjho, anunayo catutthamaggañāṇavajjho, yase pasaṃsāya ca anunayo catutthamaggañāṇavajjhoti eke.
analyzed: loka dhammesu paṭighaḥ tatiya magga ñāṇa vajjhaḥ anunayaḥ catuttha magga ñāṇa vajjhaḥ yase pasaṃsāya ca anunayaḥ catuttha magga ñāṇa vajjhaḥ ti eke
translated: In the case of the worldly states, resentment is abandoned by the third path knowledge, and approval is abandoned by the fourth path knowledge, some say.

analyzed: macchariyāni paṭhama magga ñāṇa vajjhāni eva
translated: The forms of stinginess are abandoned by the first path knowledge.

original: Vipallāsesu pana anicce niccaṃ, anattani attāti ca saññācittadiṭṭhivipallāsā, dukkhe
analyzed: vipallāsesu pana anicce niccam an attani attā ati ca saññā citta diṭṭhi vipallāsāḥ dukkhe
translated: In the case of the perversions, the perversions of perception, consciousness, and view that there is permanence in the impermanent and self in the not-self are abandoned by the first path knowledge;🔽the perversions of perception, consciousness, and view that there is pleasure in the painful and beauty in the ugly are abandoned by the third path knowledge.

original: sukhaṃ, asubhe subhanti diṭṭhivipallāso cāti ime paṭhamamaggañāṇavajjhā, asubhe subhanti
analyzed: sukham asubhe subhanti diṭṭhi vipallāso ca ati ime paṭhama magga ñāṇa vajjhāḥ asubhe subhanti
translated: and the perversion of view that consists in regarding the foul body as fair.🔽The perversions of perception and consciousness that consist in regarding the foul body as fair are abandoned by the third path.

analyzed: saññā citta vipallāsā tatiya magga ñāṇa vajjhā dukkhe sukhanti catuttha magga ñāṇa vajjhā
translated: The perversion of perception and consciousness that consists in regarding what is painful as pleasurable is abandoned by the fourth path.🔽The bodily tie of adherence to rules and vows and the bodily tie of mere-rule-following are abandoned by the first path.🔽The bodily tie of ill will is abandoned by the third path.

original: Ganthesu sīlabbataparāmāsaidaṃsaccābhinivesakāyaganthā paṭhamamaggañāṇavajjhā, byāpādakāyagantho tatiyamaggañāṇavajjho, abhijjhākāyagantho catutthamaggañāṇavajjhova.
analyzed: ganthesu sīla bbata parāmāsa edaṃsacca abhinivesa kāya ganthā paṭhama magga ñāṇa vajjhā byāpāda kāya gantho tatiya magga ñāṇa vajjho abhijjhā kāya gantho catuttha magga ñāṇa vajjhaḥ uva
translated: The bodily tie of covetousness is abandoned only by the fourth path.

analyzed: agatiyaḥ paṭhama magga ñāṇa vajjhā
translated: The wrongnesses are abandoned by the first path.🔽The taint of sensual desire is abandoned by the third path.

original: Āsavesu diṭṭhāsavo paṭhamañāṇavajjho, kāmāsavo tatiyañāṇavajjho, itare dve catutthañāṇavajjhā. Oghayogesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: āsavesu diṭṭha āsavo paṭhama ñāṇa vajjhaḥ kāma āsavaḥ tatiya ñāṇa vajjhaḥ itare dve catuttha ñāṇa vajjhāḥ ogha yogesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: The other two taints are abandoned by the fourth path. The same method applies in the case of the floods and the bonds.🔽The hindrance of uncertainty is abandoned by the first path.🔽The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, and worry are abandoned by the third path.

original: Nīvaraṇesu vicikicchānīvaraṇaṃ paṭhamañāṇavajjhaṃ, kāmacchando byāpādo kukkuccanti tīṇi tatiyañāṇavajjhāni, thinamiddhauddhaccāni catutthañāṇavajjhāni.
analyzed: nīvaraṇesu vicikicchā nīvaraṇam paṭhama ñāṇa vajjham kāmacchandaḥ byāpādaḥ kukkuccanti tīṇi tatiya ñāṇa vajjhāni thinam iddha auddhaccāni catuttha ñāṇa vajjhāni
translated: The hindrances of sloth and torpor and agitation are abandoned by the fourth path.

analyzed: parāmāsaḥ paṭhama ñāṇa vajjhaḥ
translated: Adherence to rules and vows is abandoned by the first path.

original: Upādānesu sabbesampi lokiyadhammānaṃ vatthukāmavasena “kāmā”ti āgatattā rūpārūpesu
analyzed: upādānesu sabbesam pi lokiya dhammānam vatthu kāma vasena āgata ttā rūpa arūpesu
translated: Since all the kinds of clinging are called “sensual desires” because they are the object of sensual desire, lust for the fine-material and immaterial is included in sensual desire clinging.

original: rāgopi kāmupādāne patati, tasmā tañca kāmupādānaṃ catutthañāṇavajjhaṃ, sesāni paṭhamañāṇavajjhāni.
analyzed: rāgaḥ api kāma upādāne patati tasmā tat ca kāma upādānam catuttha ñāṇa vajjham sesāni paṭhama ñāṇa vajjhāni
translated: So that clinging too is abandoned by the fourth knowledge, while the rest are abandoned by the first knowledge.

original: Anusayesu diṭṭhivicikicchānusayā paṭhamañāṇavajjhā, kāmarāgapaṭighānusayā tatiyañāṇavajjhā, mānabhavarāgāvijjānusayā catutthañāṇavajjhā.
analyzed: anusayesu diṭṭhi vicikicchā anusayā paṭhama ñāṇa vajjhā kāma rāga paṭigha anusayā tatiya ñāṇa vajjhā māna bhava rāga avijja anusayā catuttha ñāṇa vajjhā
translated: As to the inherent tendencies, the inherent tendencies to wrong view and to uncertainty are abandoned by the first knowledge, those to lust for sensual desires and to resentment are abandoned by the third knowledge, and those to conceit, lust for existence, and ignorance are abandoned by the fourth knowledge.

original: Malesu dosamalaṃ tatiyañāṇavajjhaṃ, itarāni catutthañāṇavajjhāneva.🔽Akusalakammapathesu pāṇātipāto adinnādānaṃ micchācāro musāvādo micchādiṭṭhīti ime
analyzed: malesu dosa malam tatiya ñāṇa vajjham itarāni catuttha ñāṇa vajjhāna eva  akusala kamma pathesu pāṇātipātaḥ adinnādānam micchācāraḥ musāvādaḥ micchādiṭṭhi iti ime
translated: As to the taints, the taint of ill will is abandoned by the third knowledge, while the rest are abandoned by the fourth knowledge only.

original: paṭhamañāṇavajjhā, pisuṇavācā pharusavācā byāpādoti tatiyañāṇavajjhā, samphappalāpo
analyzed: paṭhama ñāṇa vajjhā pisuṇa vācā pharusa vācā byāpādaḥ ti tatiya ñāṇa vajjhā samphappalāpaḥ

analyzed: abhijjhā
translated: and covetousness and ill will are abandoned by the fourth knowledge only.

original: Akusalacittuppādesu cattāro diṭṭhigatacittuppādā, vicikicchāsampayutto cāti pañca paṭhamañāṇavajjhā, dve paṭighasampayuttā tatiyañāṇavajjhā, sesā catutthañāṇavajjhāti.
analyzed: akusala cittuppādesu cattāro diṭṭhigata cittuppādāḥ vicikicchā sampayuttaḥ ca ati pañca paṭhama ñāṇa vajjhāḥ dve paṭigha sampayuttā tatiya ñāṇa vajjhā sesā catuttha ñāṇa vajjhā ati
translated: As regards the unprofitable consciousnesses, four are the province of the first knowledge, namely, the four consciousnesses accompanied by false view, and five are the province of the first knowledge, namely, the four consciousnesses accompanied by false view and that accompanied by doubt. Two are the province of the third knowledge, namely, those accompanied by resentment. The rest are the province of the fourth knowledge.

original: Yañca yena vajjhaṃ, taṃ tena pahātabbaṃ nāma. Tena vuttaṃ “etesaṃ saṃyojanādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ etāni yathāyogaṃ pahānakarānī”ti.

translated: And what is the province of what should be abandoned by that is called “to be abandoned by that”. Hence it was said: “These are the respective abandonings of these states beginning with the fetters”.

translated: What are the conditions? It may be stated as follows: They are of twenty-four kinds as root-cause, object, predominance, proximity, contiguity, arising together, mutuality, support, support and supported, prenascence, postnascence, repetition, kamma, kamma-result, nutriment, faculty, jhāna, path, association, dissociation, presence, absence, disappearance, and non-disappearance conditions.

translated: Herein, root-cause condition is the six dhammas beginning with greed.

original: Ārammaṇapaccayoti sabbalokiyalokuttaraṃ yaṃ yaṃ dhammaṃ ārabbha ye ye dhammā uppajjanti🔽cittacetasikā dhammā, te te dhammā tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo.🔽Adhipatipaccayoti ettha sahajātādhipatiārammaṇādhipativasena duvidho. Tattha sahajātādhipati
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccayo ti sabba lokiya lokuttaram yam yam dhammam ārabbha ye ye dhammāḥ uppajjanti  citta cetasikāḥ dhammā te te dhammā tesam tesam dhammānam ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ  adhipati paccayo ti ettha sahajāta adhipati ārammaṇa adhipati vasena duvidhaḥ tattha sahajāta adhipati
translated: Object condition is any dhamma that is the object for any dhamma of the cognizance class and cognizance class concomitant that arises.

translated: Predominance condition is twofold: conascence predominance and object predominance. original: ca aniṭṭhasammatañca rūpaṃ ṭhapetvā avasesaṃ. Anantarapaccayoti anantaraniruddhā🔽cittacetasikā dhammā. Tathā samanantarapaccayopi.

translated: and the visible data that are not agreed upon as desirable, leaving out the rest. ‘Contiguity condition’: mind and bodily-form that are ceased without a break.🔽So too with ‘proximity condition’.

translated: “Preceded by the object” means present visible data, etc., only. “Postnascence condition” means the states of consciousness and its concomitants.🔽“Repetition condition” means profitable, unprofitable, and indeterminate states of consciousness and its concomitants in the three planes, excluding the two kinds of adverting.🔽“Kamma condition” is twofold, as conascence and not as conascence.
